div.head: Act I.
Scene.—A Street in Paris, Rue de l'Echelle.
div.stage: L. H. a Shed, the interior of which faces the audience, it opens into the second room. R.H. a Nobleman's House, in the centre, at the back, is the Fountain. Streets branching from it right and left.

[As the curtain rises, Cabri and several Water Carriers are grouped around the Fountain, one after the other filling their pails. Javotte apart from them, seated on the wooden frame, which she rests upon her pails. She sings.]

sp.l: A lonely maid I've wander'd far,
And gaily met each weary day ;
For every night love's trembling star
Lighted the morrow with its ray.
The day is long, but toil is light,
And all around me happy seems ;
For when I seek repose at night,
My heart beats softly through my dreams.
I dream that he who has my heart,
Doth call me his own little wife ;
And if I wake up with a start,
I wake up to new hope, new life!
A lonely maid, &c, &c

div.stage: As Javotte finishes her song, she is going to take her place at the fountain, but Cabri places himself before her.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Back ! back ! Savoyard! It's not your turn yet.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Not my turn? why, all the girls are gone but me, and you wouldn't be so rude towards the sex, as to refuse me my share.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Pooh! Stuff! As if a Savoyard had a right to share ! go and fill your pails at the river—you don't belong to us.
sp.stage: [he is about to throw her pails aside.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [puts herself before him with her arms a-kimbo.] Touch them at your peril! Bully that you are! Oh! if I were only a man!

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: And what then, my little water wagtail ? Be off at once—away with you !

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ay ! ay ! be off!—away with you!
sp.stage: [driving her back.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [resisting] I won't stir a step, if I die for it! Cowards ! Oh ! if Brididi were but here!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Brididi!—there's a name! Who's your Brididi ? Where's your Brididi ?
sp.stage: Enter Brididi, L. H. who rushes in between them.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Here's her Brididi!—this is her Brididi! Touch her, if you dare! Don't be frightened, Javotte; we two are a match for ten such water melons as these!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha! ha ! ha! Let's duck him in the fountain—eh, lads, what do you say ?
sp.stage: [They advance towards him, and try to seize him, he resists, during which Madeleine enters R. H. U. E,]

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Heyday ! heyday ! what's all this ?

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Madame Madeleine!
sp.stage: [they all rush round her, and tell their story as fast as they can.]

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Ah ! ha! now we shall see ! Look here, madame Madeleine.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: I'll tell you all about it, aunt—I came here with my pails—

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: You see, madame Madeleine, the whole story lies in two words—this little Savoyard—

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: I'll tell you how it begun—you see, Madame Madeleine, just as we were—

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Silence! chattering magpies that you are,—one at a time ! Javotte, my child ; what's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Why you see, madame Madeleine—

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Holloa! young man—are you the child ? Is your name Javotte ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: No, madame Madeleine, only—

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, then! Now child.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: It's the old story, aunt—these rude fellows want to drive me away from the fountain.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: So much the better—I'm glad of it—I wish they'd succeed ! You ought to have more pride than to carry those nasty water pails about, and disgrace your family; Haven't I offered you a stall in the market ? Haven't I promised to get you received amongst us, and find you a husband into the bargain ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Find her a husband, I like that!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: But I don't!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: As if she could'nt find one for herself.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Be quiet, Saucebox ! [to Javotte] Have'nt I one in my eye for you ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Well, and have'nt I one in my eye for her, if you come to that.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: And have'nt I one in my own eye too, if that's all.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Ah ! but not such a one as Alcide Le Fort, the Syndic of the Market, there's a husband, if you like.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: But I don't like !

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: No, she don't like, do you Javotte ?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Young! stout! six foot high! shoulders like a wall! hands like grappling irons! there's a man to fight your battles, when such wishy washy fellows as these attempt to insult you.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Well, and can't I fight her battles too ? what's shoulders to do with it ? what's six foot high to do with it ? The heart within's the thing, isn't it Javotte ? It's the pluck, Ma'ame Madeleine, the pluck! [Looks fiercely at Cabri] A rat fights fiercer than an elephant I tell you, so don't you go deceiving the girl, don't you be deceived Javotte.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [very demurely] Nay, dear Aunt Madeleine, I'm sure whatever you advise must be for my good, and if you wish me to enter the Market, I'm willing to obey your orders. I'm meekness itself about things I don't care for, so that I'm not thwarted in what I do care for! [getting warmer] But as to the husband part of the matter, I'm all for pleasing myself I tell you, and I think I ought too, as I'm the person most concerned in the choice, after all—and I don't see how it's anybody's but mine, [in a fury] only just at this moment its got nothing to do with the question, for if I don't get the better of these rude, rough, ignorant, cowardly fellows, I feel I shall never be a wife, nor a Market Woman neither, for I shall die of downright spite and vexation, so I shall. [Bursting out crying.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: [and others] Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Don't ye cry, Javotte !

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: I will have justice if I die for it!

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Justice, will you, where will you get it ?
sp.stage: [Père Bonneau heard without crying " Water ho!"

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Here it comes, in the person of Père Bonneau, he shall be our justice, he's the foreman of their district, and will explain the rules.
sp.stage: Enter Père Bonneau, carrying his water pails, R. H.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p:
Now boys, whats the matter ? is the river run
dry, that you quarrel at the fountain ? Good day, Madeleine Richard, what brings you among us ?

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: We won't have a Savoyard encroaching on the privilege of Auvergnats.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: A fine privilege, forsooth! the privilege of a pail of water! I've as much right to it as you, the water belongs to us all—water was invented before Auvergnats were thought of!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: No, no, wench, there you are wrong, when water was invented, there was also a provision made for Auvergnats to sell it, every one knows that! We can't alter the rules.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: [and the rest] No ! we can't alter the rules!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: No we can't do that, and therefore one of them being that I, as foreman of this district, have the right of helping myself first, come when I may.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: [and the rest] Right, that's the rule !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: I intend for once to use it, and so—I give up my turn to you, there help yourself, Savoyard, and Heaven bless you!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [throwing up his cap] Hurra! long live Père Bonneau.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Oh! thank you, thank you a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Not at all, not at all, the gifts of the earth should be for all its children.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Bravo! Père Bonneau, I love you for that.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we all know the old boy's weakness, if a pretty girl only shews her face, there's an end of him.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: True, Cabri, I don't deny it, there's nothing in that, for any man to be ashamed of I fancy, especially when, like me, he thinks of his own darling child, left with her mother far away.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: The beautiful Thérèse, as you call her.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: As our whole Village calls her, I can testify ! you won't see such another in the longest day of the year.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: That you won't, though I say it, young, gay, active, loving, beautiful, virtuous, the courage of a lion, and the heart of a child. Ah! boys, it is not because she is mine that I say it, and perhaps I should'nt say it, but say it I will, when she was born, her mother and I presented the world with a paragon!

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Egad! master Bonneau, I've half a mind to ask the girl of you, for a wife at once !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Too late, my boy ; too late. She has been married next to a twelvemonth, to an excellent lad, whom she doats upon—Georges Michel, a hard working fellow, they tell me, for I never set eyes on him myself.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: No, no, Marie and I managed that business for you; we flatter ourselves Michel! a treasure—handsome to begin with and there's no harm in that, you know.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [pluming himself.] None, whatever.

sp.speaker: Madeline.
sp.p: Moreover, a scholar, educated at the College of Beauvais,!—well mannered, sober and steady. Thérèse loved him,—he loved Thérèse—what more would you have ? smack they were married at once—there was an end of that.
sp.stage: [Javotte goes up to fountain.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: What, and didn't they even invite you to the wedding ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Oh! yes, but the journey would have cost too much, so I gave it up, and sent the price of it to the young couple instead. It pleased them less, but was of more use, I know ; besides, for the matter of that, I had my share of the fun. I shut myself up in my house, there, [points to shed] with a neighbour or two, and quietly drank a bottle to their health ; that sent my brain capering, as if I had been dancing in our village: By the bye talking of our village, I have just received a letter, from home and away from my wife I can't say —is there any one of you learned enough to read it for me?

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Not I!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Nor I!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: [looking at Brididi] Eh ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [shakes his head] Ugh!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Now, if Michel were but here; he'd shew you the way!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [coming forward.] Service for service, Père
Bonneau—if you like, I will read it for you,

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Lor ! do you mean to say, that a little thing like you, can read writing all by yourself ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Read it ? like a schoolmaster!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [nudges Madeleine.] Eh ! what do you think of that?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: True! I forgot, my Javotte. Read it lass,

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [to Cabri.] There, you clown! do you hear that ? [gives letter to Javotte.] Now, read. my little wench. Oh, you may all hear— there are no secrets in Bonneau's family! It's signed "Thérèse," I suppose : isn't it ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: No ! it's signed "Michel."

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: It's the same thing—wife or husband, you know

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Is it ? how much he knows about it!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [reading.] "Père Bonneau! when you get this, I shall have left home, and my dearly loved Thérèse"—

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Left home ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p:
[reads] "In the village, here, there is no work to be got—I am ambitious, and I have the prospect of fortune for myself, for dear Thérèse, beyond the seas. She tells me, there is at Paris, a rich and powerful nobleman, who will, if you ask bim, get me a free passage from Bordeaux; I wait your reply, there. If you can't procure me the passage, I shall work my way out before the mast. Pray for my good
fortune and speedy return to dear, dear Thérèse—for I shall return rich, or not at all!"
Your Son, Michel."

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Poor lad ! Poor Thérèse!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Don't be down hearted, Père Bonneau—Michel is a brave lad—I like his spirit, and he'll succeed, I'll answer for him!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [shouldering her pails.] Ay, ay, that's all very well- but meantime, Thérèse will be all but a widow. She shouldn't have let her husband go—eh, Brididi ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Certainly not!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Wait till I get one— I won't let him go again in a hurry, I promise you;—eh, Brididi ? [Exit L. U. E. singing.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Certainly not! [Exit after her.
sp.stage: [During what follows, the water carriers are filling their pails, and one by one going off down the streets, R. and L.]

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: And who is the rich nobleman, whose protection you rely upon.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: The Marquis de Melcy, my neighbour; [points to house, R] but he wants protection himself, just now, poor fellow, and would be glad of a free passage anywhere. Three weeks ago, he was arrested, thrown into the Bastile, and seals placed upon every room in his house.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: So I've heard.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: But what has he done ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Written something or other—I don't know what —but you may suppose it wasn't very right, since they threw him into prison for it.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: I say, madame Madeleine, reading and writing isn't all profit after all!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: And everybody cries out against him except me

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Why except you ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Madeleine Richard, I am not scholar enough to understand the harm he has written, but I have heart enough to comprehend the good he has done !

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Père Bonneau—kiss me! [Bonneau kisses her] That's done me good! You're one of those sort of men, look you, that—no matter—I must be off to market!
sp.stage: [Exit, U. E. L. H.

A sedan chair, in which is Madame St. Prie, appears in the street. L. H. U. E . On passing Bonneau she coughs, he looks up, recognises her and bows. Cabri goes to fountain, fills his pails and those of Bonneau. Madame St. Prie returning Bonneau's salute with her hand, drops her handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Stop! Stop! [the sedan chair stops.) Bonneau, will you be kind enough—

sp.speaker: Bonneau.

p.stage: [picking it up and presenting the handkerchief.]

sp.p: Certainly! have I the honor to be remembered, madam ?

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Oh ! yes you are Père Bonneau—[mysteriously] an honest, grateful man! Is it not so ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [confused] Madame! [aside.] What the deuce does she say that for ?

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: You live in this street, I believe?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: There's my mansion, madam, [pointing to shed] at your service.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: And you live there alone—quite alone ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Quite alone.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: [in under tone.] Come nearer. [he is astonished.] Fear nothing,—come close !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: There I am.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: [confidentially.] Bonneau, I came here to seek you.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: To seek me ?

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Yes—to tell you to be at home at sunset—at home, and alone.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: For what ?

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: A precious life depends on it.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: That's enough, I'll be here.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: St. Prie.[to Porters] Home !
sp.stage: [She is carried away by the small street, R. H. U. R.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Hum !—a precious life depends on it ! of course, I shall be here at sunset. I've time enough to serve a customer or two and be back. [takes up his pails.] Hollo ! why my pails are full!

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Of course, they are ! while you were chattering with the fine lady, I was doing your work for you, old boy.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Good lad ! good lad !
sp.stage: [Voices heard from the Marquis's House, R. H.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: I say—they seem turning everything topsy-turvy inside.

sp.speaker: Philippe.
sp.p: [inside.] I tell you, those are my orders!

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: I tell you, they don't apply to me!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Oh ! it's Baptiste, the marquis's coachman, who came for his things, and Philippe, the porter, won't let him have them, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Serve him right—the drunken dog ! If they'd clapped the seals upon him, it would have been better for all the neighbours

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p:
All except the wine merchants, Cabri! Come, let's go, or they'll mix us up in the quarrel. [shoulders his
pails.] Water! any water, oh ! [Exit with Cabri, U. E. L. H.
sp.stage: [The noise increases. Baptiste appears, as if ejected from the gate, with a bundle under his arm.]

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Was there ever such a chap ? Wouldn't even let me take away my own clothes. That's a good idea! they don't belong to the marquis's wardrobe— they are not political articles !—government may seize everything belonging to him, and welcome—I could sit down calmly under that—but for government to touch the coachman's livery—it's enough to make any patriot's blood boil! It's Despotism! I think it's quite enough to lose so good a place—Oh! what a place it was ! Nothing to do, but receive one's wages, and ride about on a comfortable coach-box—corn in abundance—a first rate kitchen, and a cellar—oh ! what a cellar!
sp.stage: Enter Gaspard at the back, in a travelling dress, looks about him ; — he examines the House, R. H., then notices Baptiste.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside] Common looking fellow !—sottish face -tipsy legs !—bundle under his arm!—and in the melancholy attitude of a coachman out of place. The very man I was looking after !

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Ah ! that was a cellar! Poor marquis! who will drink his wine for him, now, that I am not there ?
sp.stage: [sighs and opens his snuff box

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [advancing, takes a pinch.] Snuff, too! Another bad habit! The scamp has nothing to learn. [enjoying the pinch.] Upon my word ! Exquisite ! Where did you steal that?

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Where did I buy it ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Steal it.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: [exasperated] Sir, do you know the man you are talking to ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Perfectly, I can send him to the galleys in five minutes.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: [mildly] Oh! to whom have I the pleasure of speaking ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: To a friend or a foe, as the case may be M. Baptiste.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: You know my name

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And your occupation, you are Baptiste by name, a coachman by nature, a sloth and a sot by profession, mixed up in a certain awkward affair of corn and hay, born with the brass to commit, without the wit to conceal. In short, a fool turned up with a knave.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: [laughing] Ah! you wag, I see you know me!
In the same line perhaps

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p:
I, Gaspard L'Avisé, who have represented in my own person the Majesty of the Law, as an Attorney's Clerk, the Grace of Literature as a Writing master, and the Dignity of
Commerce, as a Smuggler! I who can carry on a dozen affairs at once, without confusion, I in the same line with a clumsy fellow who can't even drive a pair of horses, without bumping against the posts ! Learn to appreciate better the barrier which nature has set up between us!

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Beg pardon, but as you alluded to that little matter of corn and hay—

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Which passed through my master's office—

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Oh ! I understand, but you won't betray me—I'm looking out for another place, and if that matter were raked up, you know—people have such queer prejudices, I might never get into service again.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Pooh ! I'll take you into mine.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: You ! why, you don't mean to say you have a house in Paris ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I mean to say nothing of the kind, I have but this moment jumped off the Diligence, and the street is my only home. One of the airiest apartments in all Paris.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: But, to morrow!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: To morrow I am off to St. Domingo.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: And I'm to follow you ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: No, I want you here.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: What wages am I to have ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Twenty Louis.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: A year ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: A day—there are two to begin with, [gives money] you are a coachman, I take you by the hour.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: [taking off his hat) Where shall I drive you, Sir ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Into that house silently! [pointing to house R. H.] Shew me where to find the Marquis's will, and tell me all you know about his son.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: In the first place, there's no getting into the house—in the second, I know nothing of any will—in the third, they have clapped seals every where—in the fourth, I never heard of a son.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [looking at him with intense pity] Numscull! to have lived with the Marquis, worn his livery, and never learned his secrets.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Don't care about his secrets, my inclination does not lead me that way, but I can give you every information about the cellar.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I hoped to have discovered something from man, who had had every opportunity of knowing all, and yet here am I, a stranger but just landed, obliged to inform him that there is a will hidden within these walls, and that there is a son, though brought up in secret somewhere in the country, though where, and under what name, I have yet to find out,

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: And how the devil did you come to find out all this ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I'll tell you. From my master—Monseigneur, the Duke de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: The Marqnis's father ! —your master—why, then you are nothing but a servant, after all ? [puts on his hat.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: During the last six months I have been the Duke's confidant and factotum; he took an immense and immediate fancy to me—a man of great discernment, the Duke! Appointed governor of St. Domingo, he received at the moment of his departure, a letter from the Marquis, announcing his arrest; and the fact that he had left a will among his papers, revealing the existence of a son, whom he had brought up in secret, because the child's mother had proved herself unworthy to bear the name of de Melcy. This son he commended to the protection of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Oh ! the Duke then is afraid lest the will should be mislaid, and he has commissioned you to secure it, and bring him his grandson with the title; I understand all

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You understand nothing. The Duke is too proud of his family to allow of the introduction of one whose birth—

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Is he illegitimate then ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: No—but the son of a woman of no family—a woman by whom the Marquis was fascinated, and whom he married secretly; fortunately before the marriage was avowed, he learnt that his wife was worthless, as well as birthless, and so discarded her. Now, I am at all hazards, to secure the will and carry it to St. Domingo, for which service I am to receive ten thousand francs. So to work—where did the marquis keep his papers ?

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: All I know is, that in that room—[pointing to the window.] The Marquis's study—there is a cabinet, where he used to write, and lock up important letters.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: That will do—to-morrow its contents are mine.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: To-morrow ? But the seals are to be removed to-day !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: The devil they are ? To-day !—then there's no time to lose—it will be sharp work!

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: By Jupiter it will, for here comes old Gobinard, the Commissary of Police, for the very purpose, so there's an end of you at once.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: So, it is old Gobinard himself, sure enough.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Do you know him ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Is there a Commissary of Police in Europe I don't know ? step this way. [Retires L.H.
sp.stage: Enter Gobinard and his Boy with papers, Gobinard is going towards the house R. H., when he stops suddenly.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p:
On second thoughts I shall not want you—go
back to Madame Gobinard, and tell her she can go at once to her uncle's to supper without waiting for me—and when I've done, I'll go and fetch her home, stop—stop giddy pate, don't carry away my papers!
sp.stage: [Goes up towards the Fountain, gives his Boy directions. Exit Boy, U. E. R. H., stage begins to darken slowly.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Poor Madame Gobinard, a pretty little woman, young enough to bury three such old Mummies as that.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Do you know her ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Of course, she's the cousin of one of my old fellow clerks, Isidore Patrat.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: There he comes again, he's going to the Marquis's.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: No, he isn't— do you run for a hackney coach, make the coachman drunk, you know how to do that, take his seat, be on the watch, and when I beckon to you, draw up.
sp.stage: [Pushes him off, L. H.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: [sorting his papers, and coming down] I believe I've got all the papers I want.
sp.stage: [As he is about to knock at the house R. H., Gaspard places his hand upon his arm.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Stop, you're my prisoner !

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: I , your prisoner ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Yes, I arrest you !

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: What, you arrest me! Why, I am the Commissary of Police my friend, it is I who arrest others, take care what you're about.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: It is for your good I arrest you.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: That's another affair, but quick, be brief, I have work to do in that house.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You need'nt hurry yourself there, there's more pressing business for you than that elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: On the contrary, I have received positive orders to remove the seals, and forward all the Marquis's papers at once to the Judge—no business can be more pressing.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Well, its all a matter of taste certainly. So then, if some one were to bring you word that your house was on fire, or your wife run away with, you would remain quietly where you are, and consider the public affairs before you own ?

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: Not at all. Remain here indeed, and quietly! what an idea ! luckily, however, my house is not on fire, and as to my wife— [About to knock.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You fancy she is safe at home, I suppose!

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: Of course I do -nay I don't fancy it, I know it; where should she be ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Why, where she should'nt be, of course. Confiding individual! Candid Commissary ! Innocent husband! no sooner had you turned upon your heel, than she was off—

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: To sup with her uncle.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: To sup with her cousin.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: Isidore!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Patrat, Clerk in the Customs, a dissipated young dog, fond of wine and women, and doating upon his cousin, with whom he has a rendezvous this evening. Why, he was boasting of it, not half an hour ago, in my presence, the scapegrace ! boasting of his treason, and laughing at your shame! I had not the honour of knowing you, respectable M. Gobinard, of personally knowing you, but said I to myself, "Dubois," said I, "you are a married man, and one who has suffered bitterly, from the conduct of Mrs D —, it is your duty to enlighten the respectable and respected Gobinard." It was my duty—and as in Russia strangers charitably stop you with a warning that your nose is freezing, so do I stop you with a warning that your forehead is on fire. There, now you are warned. Be deceived, duped, laughed at, if you like—but don't say you are not warned. At any rate, I have done my duty, and I wash my hands of the matter— Sir, I have the honour of wishing you good evening.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: [staying him] But my dear sir, it is impossible!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And therefore true.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: But my wife can't bear her cousin Isidore, she is always speaking ill of him.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: A sure sign, that she thinks well of him.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: She has made me forbid him my house !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: That she may visit him at his.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: She thinks him hideous !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And you know he's handsome.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: That's what she says I am.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And you are as ugly as sin. Excuse my frankness but you must confess you are damnably ugly.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: You think so ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Unmistakeably!

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: To think of my wife! To tell you the truth, I always suspected as much.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Look you there now! oh! a man of your sagacity could not do otherwise.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: Perfidious woman, but I will surprise her. [Going.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Burst upon her.

sp.speaker: Gobiinard.
sp.p: I fly, but it's such a deuce of a distance.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And you hav'nt a minute to lose! Mercy on us ! a minute did I say ? a minute and you may be too late! I'd take a coach, if I were you! By the bye, I have one here, I just engaged by the hour—I'll lend it to you. Between husbands there should be community of interests—you shall have my coach.
sp.stage: [Beckons to Baptiste.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: How can I return your civility ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Don't think of returning at all, I beg you won't.
sp.stage: Enter Baptiste, with a whip in his hand, L. H.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Now, sir.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You must drive this gentleman where he wishes

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: And gallop like a race horse, d'ye hear ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside] Gallop like a tortoise, d'ye hear ?

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: Like lightning!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Like a snail—remember you're by the hour.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Ay, ay , I haven't forgotten that, nor the price you're to pay for it.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: Come! Come! Oh! sir, how shall I ever! come along ! [Drags off Baptiste, L. U. E.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: That's all right! Now if Baptiste only keeps him off for one hour, the trick's complete ! I thought his wife would be a safe lure. How devilish ready men are to believe any ill of their wives ! Now for my part of the farce ! There's not an instant to lose. [runs off up street, R. U . E.
sp.stage: Enter Père Bonneau, L. U. E.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Evening draws in, and I am here at my post. [He opens the door of his shed, ranges his buckets, and strikes a light with flint and steel, lights a candle, &c., &c] So there's somebody's life depending on me, is there ? Well, if I can save him, saved he is !
sp.stage: Enter Madame St. Prie— she is dressed plainly.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Bonneau !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Is that you, Madame, and in such a dress ?

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: I must not be recognised I come to ask your assistance—your protection!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: For yourself?

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: For the Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: The Marquis de Melcy!—my assistance!—he shall have my life! Oh! could I but get him out of the Bastile!

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: That's done already.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Already ? The marquis has been liberated!

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: By my means—he will be here directly, but must remain no longer than the time sufficient to exchange his dress for a suit of yours.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: He shall have it—I've a new suit of clothes all ready made for Thérèse's wedding, and never put on; he shall have the hanselling of them.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: By favor of that disguise, he may reach the Quai de Chaillot, where a post chaise awaits him.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: You have thought of everything, I see.
sp.stage: Enter the Marquis, stealthily and hesitatingly at back,

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p:
But the time is past when he should be here.
What can delay him ? Good heavens! should he have been discovered—or should the jailor have played me false!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Stay! There's a man there, surely ; yonder, in the dark—he's coming towards us

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: It is the Marquis!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: You may venture this way, sir—there's nothing to fear from us.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: [advances, looks at Madame St. Prie, but without recognising her] Bonneau, my good friend ! And is it to you I owe my deliverance ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: To me ? unhappily, no !—I wish it were! Here is your deliverer.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: [recognizing her.] Coralie ! [taking her by the hand.]

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Did not your heart tell you ?

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: I did not know you were in Paris. And have you flown to me in the hour of danger ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: While you are chatting, I will get out the suit of clothes we were talking of for you. [enters his house, 2 E.L.H.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Marquis ! I ask not for a husband's love— he has long withdrawn it from me, with his name; which he refuses to let me bear: and his child, whom he refuses to let me see. I ask not for his love, my own heart is dead to it; but I ask for that justice which no honorable man can now withhold. I ask for his recognition of my innocence!

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: Coralie ! it is yours, and with it my repentance.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: And with it your son ?—you hesitate! For years you have made me suffer the penalty of your unjust suspicions—for years you have refused to see me, to acknowledge me as your wife; to let me behold my child, and all because you believed an idle calumny, rather than the mother of your boy :—and now—now that the calumny has been at last avowed, now that you know you had no cause to blush for your wife, except for her humble birth ; now when I demand the reparation I have a right to claim, you hesitate.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: Your son shall be restored to you, our marriage shall be avowed—I have already avowed it in my will. If I hesitated, it was—
sp.stage: Enter Bonneau.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: All's ready—we'd better not loiter.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Quick! in at once—the travelling carriage is waiting at the Quai de Chaillot,—I'll go forward, and meet you there.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: And as we fly from Paris, we will talk of our dear boy, and the pleasure of meeting him again.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p:
Shall I indeed see him ? Shall I call him mine, and press him to this heart ? Oh, happiness! But there
is not a second to lose—haste! haste and rejoin me without delay. [Exit R.H. U. E.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Now, to equip you. It's not a very smart suit for a marquis, but you'll be one of the best dressed water carriers in all Paris, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: Bonneau, I have another service to beg of you.
In a few days my son will be in Paris, he will ask for you—

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Your son !—is it possible ? —

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: [continues without heeding him] He will require money to enable him to follow us. There is in my house a sum of two hundred Louis d'ors.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: But you dare not venture into it.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: Venture I must—ay, even at the risk of being discovered. Who is there now ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Philippe, the Porter. They've left him there to guard the seals.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: Philippe will not betray his master.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: You must not trust him, indeed, you must not— the risk is too terrible to think of.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: But my son's welfare requires it.
sp.stage: [He is about to go towards the house, R. H. when Bonneau, who has gone up the stage rapidly descends.]

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Quick ! quick ! into my house!

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: Wherefore ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: The Commissary of Police is here.
sp.stage: [He drags in the Marquis, and keeps the door ajar, to watch what goes on.]
Enter Gaspard, disguised as a Commissary, with spectacles, wig, & c. A boy precedes him with a lantern.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Now then, you young rascal; where are you leading me to ? Did I not tell you the Hotel de Melcy ?

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: [to Bonneau.] They are passing on, are they not ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: No, they are going to examine your house. You see, if you had been one minute there, you would have been lost !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Knock at the gate, and say who's here.
sp.stage: [Boy knocks.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Look !—you can see them yourself.
sp.stage: [Marquis looks through the door.

sp.speaker: Philippe.
sp.p: Who's there ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: The Commissary of Police! In the name of the law, I am come to break the seals, and take possession of every scrap of writing to be found in the place.

sp.speaker: Philippe.
sp.p: Well, but I thought it was Gobinard had that to do.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p:
You were right, but my friend Gobinard has been forced to delegate his office to me, in consequence of a domestic
calamity, an accident, a conjugal accident; Come, sir—come take the light, and lead on! open every door, light every candle, and remember that you have now the honor of illuminating a Public Functionary.
sp.stage: [Exeunt into the house, R. H.
Bonneau and the Marquis come out of Shed, L. H.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: You see, you see, what an escape you have had.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: What is to be done ? my son will be left without resources.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Tell me where the money is to be found, and I'll manage it. I serve the house with water, and Philippe expects me presently, so that I have a good excuse for getting in.
sp.stage: [While he speaks, he gets his buckets, and goes to fill them at the Fountain.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: Once there, if you can but manage to get into the boudoir, behind the sofa is a small panel in the woodwork, which conceals a recess, there you will find the money in a bag.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: And where am I to send it ?

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: I'll write to him minute instructions, while you are gone. At present he does not even know the name of his father—he has been brought up in the country, far away from me—I have a long and painful history to tell him.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Meantime go in—put on the things I have prepared for you.
sp.stage: [Takes up his buckets, and is going off R. H. 3 E.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: But where are you going ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Round the back way—men of my sort are not good enough to enter houses by the front gate. [Exit R.H.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: Now for my disguise.
sp.stage: [He enters the shed, shuts the door after him, takes the lighted candle, and disappears into the room at back, at the same time enter Gobinard, preceded by a Boy with a lantern, and followed by two bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: Perfidious woman, it was too true! tete-a-tete with her cousin sure enough. Lucky I was in time! But now she is safely under lock and key, and shall remain so. Knock at the door, sirrah—in the name of the law, knock.
sp.stage: [Boy knocks, Philippe opens.

sp.speaker: Philippe.
sp.p: Who's there now ?

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: It's I, my good friend. Gobinard ! come at last to break the seals.

sp.speaker: Philippe.
sp.p: They're almost all broken already, your deputy has made quick work of it, I can tell you!

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: My deputy ?

sp.speaker: Philippe.
sp.p: Yes, and a sharp fellow he is, his nose is everywhere.

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: There's some mistake ! my deputy !

sp.speaker: Philippe.
sp.p: What ! did'nt you send him ?

sp.speaker: Gobinard.
sp.p: Fool, you have been the dupe of some thief, follow me quick ! [to Bailiffs] and we'll unmask the rascal who has dared to usurp my office. [Exeunt into house, R. H.
sp.stage: The Marquis appears in the shed, dressed as a Water Carrier.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: All seems quiet, I may venture now, a few lines to my son, and then away ! but hark! what noise is that ?
sp.stage: [Distant noise, gradually getting more distinct, till the words "Fire! Fire!" are clamourously heard. People rush in from R. U. E., water carriers, soldiers, firemen, market men and women, crying " Fire!" bells ring, the firemen cross the stage with the engine, the glare of the distant fire is visible, the water carriers form a line, and hand the buckets from one to the other, the people knock at the house doors, and the inhabitants come out — great confusion.

sp.speaker: 1st Man.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: The Opera is in flames.

sp.speaker: Sergeant.
sp.p: Everybody fall in rank.

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: [listening] The Opera on fire !

sp.speaker: Sergeant.
sp.p: [Knocking at door of Shed] Open! open I say !

sp.speaker: Marquis.
sp.p: [puts out candle] I dare'nt refuse, they will burst open the door! [opens door] What do you want, what is the matter ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant.
sp.p: You, a water carrier, and in doors still!—for shame ! out with you, and fall into the rank !
sp.stage: [Sergeant drags the Marquis to the fountain — the line is formed—buckets are passed on.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Mercy on us !—there is no more water—no more water!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: And none either at the Traversine Fountain !

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Friends, we must haste to the Chateau d'Eau! We shall get plenty there.
sp.stage: [The crowd rushes off. The Marquis is hurried along with them. The glare of the fire becomes more and more intense.]
Enter Bonneau, R. U. E.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Here they are—I've got the precious Louis d'ors— safe in my bucket. But what's this, eh ; a fire ? I thought I heard the shouts of fire ! and Père Bonneau not at it! I'll just put away the money, and be with them in an instant.
sp.stage: [Goes into his shed, and disappears. The window of the House R. H., which faces the audience, is thrown open, Gaspard appears.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p:
Ha ! ha ! hunt away my fine fellows—I've got the
will, and the door's barricaded. They can't get in for some minutes yet!
sp.stage: [He climbs down from the window, meanwhile a crowd of people tumultuously rush in, bearing the Marquis insensible.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: The roof has fallen in!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: I'm afraid this man is badly hurt.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: I recognize him through his disguise—it is the Marquis de Melcy!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: And dead!

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Quite dead!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [coming from his shed.] The money is safe, and the Marquis's son may come when he likes.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [who meanwhile has reached the ground, and come forward, looks at Marquis] The Marquis dead!—and the will in my hands! The ten thousand francs are in my pocket!

div.stage: [Exit, R. H. U. E.
Tableau.

div.head: Act II.
A Storm At Sea.
div.stage: The Scene represents the open Sea in the midst of a Hurricane. A large dismasted Vessel tossed on the tempest is seen rolling heavily among the billows. Four or five only of the crew are left on the wreck, and are clinging to the spars and broken mast. At intervals between the roar of the ocean and the peals of thunder, broken sentences are caught from those on board; the following being more distinctly heard:

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Michel! Michel! rouse man! Come nearer and hold on by the mast.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: I have no strength left! I am cold—exhausted!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: We are in sight of land I tell you, and if the wreck will but float a short time longer, we shall be on the rocks of St. Domingo.
sp.stage: [A terrific peal of Thunder is heard — the lightning runs along the sky, and the vessel goes down bodily, amidst a shriek from those on board. The waves wash over her, and nothing is seen but the open sea. In a few seconds two men are visible buffeting with the waves, and Gaspard crawls on to a small rock on the foreground.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [amidst the breakers] Gaspard, save me ! save me!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: In a minute—hold on but a minute. [Opens a wallet which hangs round his neck, and takes out the will] The will is safe, and scarcely even wet! Now, lad, for you.
sp.stage: [Drags Michel on shore.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [dropping senseless on the rock.] Farewell Thérèse! dear Thérèse!

div.stage: Tableau.

div.head: Act III.
Interior of Therese's Shop.
div.stage: An Orange Merchants'. Open at the backs looking upon the Market shewing the various stalls and seats under large umbrellas, and with a view of the Fountain of the Innocents, in the distance. At the commencement of the scene, Madeleine Richard is seated on a chair in the centre as President, and on stools on each side of her Fanchette, Louison, Margot, Manon, Lolotte, and other Market Women, in council.

sp.l: Now girls in council we are met,
To decide upon the merits of this pretty little Pet;
Javotte's all right and need'nt fret,
She'll be sure to be received into our set.
We shall see what she can do,
And shall hear her notions too,
Though its clear and plain,
By her Aunt Madeleine,
She's been taught as much as any of us knew.
Now, Girls, &c., &c.

sp.speaker: Margot.
sp.p: Now, Madeleine, where's this girl of yours ? we can't stay here dilly dallying all day!

sp.speaker: Lolotte.
sp.p: No sharp's the word, we must get to work !

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: All in good time, ladies, she is only putting on her cap and her best jacket, to do you honor.

sp.speaker: Manon.
sp.p: What's the cap for ? Best take it off, I say, and let's see what's under it.

sp.speaker: Louison.
sp.p: Ha ! ha! well said, Manon, and the jacket, too ! We can tell a walnut best, with the shell off.

sp.speaker: Lolotte.
sp.p: And an orange when its peeled.

sp.speaker: Margot.
sp.p: She's not butter, I suppose ! she can bear the sun.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: No, nor eggs neither, to be cheapened by any one, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Margot.
sp.p: Well, it's time we got some fresh hands into the Market, for I think the deuce is in the girls now-a-days—there's no keeping them here at all.

sp.speaker: Manon.
sp.p:
Why, there's Françoise gone now too—the fat old
Egg Merchant's daughter, gone off with an English Milord they say.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Married!

sp.speaker: Fanchette.
sp.p: Next to it, her mother says if she isn't she will, be, and that's all the same thing in the end you know.

sp.speaker: Louison.
sp.p: Well, so it is. At any rate, it's better than Georgette's stupidity. You remember her ? the handsome blonde, who used to keep the Flower Stall over the way, and attract so many customers to the Market.

sp.speaker: Margot.
sp.p: Well, what's she been and done ?

sp.speaker: Louison.
sp.p: Married in earnest an old miser, with a face like a medley, and legs like sugar tongs.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Ta! ta! ta! what's the use of raking up all this rubbish ? Javotte's none of these—where she's planted, there she grows— and if she marries at all, it shall be within the precincts of the Market.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: That's right Madeleine !

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Right, I believe you! isn't she my niece, and brought up with my principles ? I'm not like our neighbour, Nannette Souffle, who married her daughter to a Shoemaker, who looked down upon her as if she'd been an old slipper! none of that for me ! the best way to make one's children respect one's calling, is to marry them into it, and keep up the race.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bravo, well spoken, Madeleine! that's something like!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: And here she comes to pass her examination, attention !
sp.stage: Enter Javotte, C. curtseying on all sides.

sp.speaker: Margot.
sp.p: So, young woman, you want to be admitted into the Market do you ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [curtseying] If you please Ma'am, if you've no objection.

sp.speaker: Lolotte.
sp.p: Well answered.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: I believe you too.

sp.speaker: Manon.
sp.p: But do you know the duties of the situation ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Ma'am! [Curtseying.

sp.speaker: Louison.
sp.p: Do you know what you'll have to do ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [Curtseying] Saving your presence, a great many things.

sp.speaker: Fanchette.
sp.p: Let's hear some of them.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: First, there's to be up at daybreak, to get the first chance, then to try and get served before one's turn, to fight for one's place, when somebody else has taken it—to be good friends with the Market Women, and coax the Inspectors.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Very well, very well, not bad.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Isn't she a lamb ?

sp.speaker: Manon.
sp.p: What's the first rule of selling ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: To set off the worst things to the greatest advantage that they may get bought before the good ones.

sp.speaker: Manon.
sp.p: What must you do when masters and mistresses come to market themselves ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Charge them double, to sicken them from coming again.

sp.speaker: Louison.
sp.p: And when the servants come ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Charge them only fifty per cent more than the worth, and share the difference.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: You see how she has been brought up eh ! she'll be an ornament to the Market.

sp.speaker: Lolotte.
sp.p: But they'll find you out at last, what then ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Why then they'll beat me down, and be happy.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Very well, she'll do, she'll do!

sp.speaker: Margot.
sp.p: And if one of us were to try and get away your customers ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [curtseys] I should have too much respect to remonstrate.

sp.speaker: Margot.
sp.p: Hollo, that won't do ?

sp.speaker: Louison.
sp.p: And if a buyer were to abuse you ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: I should be all sweetness in return—you can't catch flies with vinegar.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh, that won't do, that won't do at all!

sp.speaker: Fanchette.
sp.p: And if, on the other hand, he were to try and coax you over ?

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: I'd let him coax me, and thank him for the honor of his custom.
sp.stage: [The women all look at each other, and shake their heads.

sp.speaker: Lolotte.
sp.p: So, then your notion of a Market Woman is—

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: That she should be civil with everybody, sharp with nobody, and by not frightening her customers away, never have her goods left on her hands.

sp.speaker: Margot.
sp.p: Well, ladies, what do you say ?
sp.stage: [They all rise, and consult together for a moment, Madeleine makes faces at Javette, and threatens her

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: You stupid little donkey.

sp.speaker: Manon.
sp.p: [with solemnity] Young woman, on mature deliberation, we have come to the opinion that you are not yet sufficiently advanced in the profession, to be admitted amongst us, and you are therefore adjourned accordingly.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [crying] Adjourned!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: I knew you would overdo it, with your sugar mouthed nonsense.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [crying] Well, it wasn't my fault—I thought a Market Woman ought to be civil and obliging—I did'nt mean any harm.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: There, now she's snivelling! she only wants that to settle her in the eyes of the Market.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [in a rage] The Market, the Market, the name of the Market! what do I care for the Market ? Did I want to come into it ? Was'nt I happy with my water pails and my Brididi ? and a fool I was I'm sure to leave 'em, to mix with a set of tawdry tits—

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Javotte!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: And so they are, a set of oyster wenches, fish fags—

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Javotte, Javotte, you'll make them angry.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: I don't care, so they are, milk maids, apple women, cabbage sellers, let 'em come on! I'm not afraid of the whole market! [Puts her arms a-kimbo.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo ! there's spirit, there's spirit!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Come, come, she'll do!
Now what say you ?
She may safely be admitted here,
I see you think so, too.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.l: What care I, Ma'am for such as you ?
To your anger I say nothing but pooh! pooh!
As for you, proud Madame Frail,
And for you Ma'am Draggletail;
I don't care a fig !
For your looks so big,
Nor for you, you mopstick stuck upon a pail.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Come, come, she'll do!
Now, what say you ?
She may safely be admitted here—
I see you think so too.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.l: Come on—let's see what you can do—
I don't want to be admitted among such a set as you
Come on— let's see what you can do—
To your anger I say nothing but pooh! pooh !

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Bravo ! bravo ! Received by acclamation!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Received ! you don't mean that ?
sp.stage: [embraces them all, ending with Madeleine.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Ah ! I told you what an angel she was. She'll hold her own with the best among us.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Oh! how happy I am—and how I wish Brididi had been here!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Brididi ! Fiddle-de-dee! I've something in my eye better than Brididi for you !

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Something in your eye again? oh, dear! aunt— you've always got something in your eye.
sp.stage: Marie heard singing without, C. L. H.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here comes Marie—here's Marie Bonneau—and little Edouard.
sp.stage: Enter Marie singing, leading Edouard by the hand.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Good day, Marie—good day—good day Edouard !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Good day, girls—good day, Madeleine ! why how pleased you all look ! what's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Javotte's just passed the scrutiny, and has been received into the Market.

sp.speaker: Marie.
All.
sp.p: A bouquet ?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter with you, Marie ? you've got on your Sunday gown, too; and look so full of joy—what's it all about ?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, what's it all about ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: All in good time. Run along, and do as I bid you ; and when you come back I'll let you into the secret—but mum ! not a word, till I tell you!
sp.stage: [Exeunt Market Women, all but Madeleine and Javotte.
sp.p: Now, stand still ; there's a dear !

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: I won't have my hair curled !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Nonsense, dear—you'll never be a man, and ride on donkey, if you don't!

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: Oh ! then I will, if Grandpa Bonneau'll give me another ride.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I'll take care of that!

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: [Letting fall the sign which he has been removing from over the door.] Heads below !

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Heyday! why, Marie, what's he about ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Hollo, sir !—what are you doing there ?

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Hush ! ma'am Bonneau—not a word.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: But what business have you here?

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: Never mind me—I'm only carrying off the sign-board.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Well, you're a cool fellow !—to morrow I shall find you busy at the till, and then I suppose you'll say, " never mind me, I'm only carrying off the money!" And pray who gave you permission to touch that sign ?

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: No one gave me permission—I was ordered by Alcide Le Fort, the Syndic of the Millers.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Oh! if Alcide ordered you, that's another thing. Ay, ay; Alcide has a certain readiness with his arms, which makes his logic very striking.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: What a fist he has to be sure.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [aside to Madeleine] Do you hear that, I don't like such fists.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: I should know it among a thousand!
sp.stage: [Alcide Le Fort, who has entered during the last few sentences, places his hand suddenly on Cabri's head.

sp.speaker: Cabri.
sp.p: That's it, I'll swear to it, oh !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Let him alone Alcide, you'll crack him like a filbert.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Off with you, chatterbox! [Kicks him off.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [aside to Madeleine] Did you see that ?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: [shrugs her shoulders] He's so playful! But here's another dressed out in his Sunday clothes, why what—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Have patience, and you shall see, what you shall see.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Very well, but you'll own such a coat as that's enough to—

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Enough to drive one mad! I only wish I had the rascal who made it, under my thumb, I'd make him remember it—the seams crack as I walk, and I daren't lift my arms, for fear the sleeves should drop off.
sp.stage: Brididi puts in his head, C.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Ma'am Bonneau—

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [Runs to him] There's Brididi, give me joy Brididi, I'm received, I'm received.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Javotte for ever !

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: Ah! there's Brididi! ah Brididi! [Runs to him.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: You have'nt seen Thérèse's lodger, Monsieur Victor, have you ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Monsieur Victor ! no, lad, he has not been here since I came in.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Yes, Monsieur Alcide, my niece Javotte, now belongs to the Market, and though I say it, is a wife for an Emperor. Curtsey Javotte. What do you think of her ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Urn, she's a little one !

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: A nice little one !
sp.stage: [During the whole of this scene, Madeleine nudges Javotte, to make her notice Alcide, and leave Brididi, and to make Alcide notice her.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Isn't that Brididi ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [timidly] At your service, Syndic!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Ain't you ashamed of yourself, you young rascal, ashamed to shew your face among those who work for their bread, and you who only beg for your's! to think of a fellow with shoulders like his, passing his day at the church door, with his hands held out.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: You're right, it is a shame, sure enough—its a bad trade, but it's the only one I was brought up to.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p:
Ay, it's not the lad's fault. One fine morning he was found in a shawl, under the church portico by old Brigitte, who begs there. She took possession of him on account of his
beauty—you would'nt think it to look at him, but he was lovely in long clothes.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: And old Brigette brought me up as a child of her own—she was a mother to me, bless her—and the Parish adopted me.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Yes, but she made a beggar of you !

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Poor old soul, she knew no better. But though I beg in public for Brigitte, I work in private for myself. Yes and to-morrow my apprenticeship expires, to-morrow I reach the dignity of a tailor! Yesterday I turned out my first coat! A coat of which an artist might be proud, and to-morrow I begin to receive wages.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Your hand, young'un, ah ! there goes another seam.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: And so you are a tailor, after all, [aside, contemptuously to Javotte] A tailor!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: And a very good thing too, a tailor!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: You'd say so, I flatter myself, if you could see the coat I made! oh, such a coat! it made one's mouth water to look at it! my master Rigobert himself, was in ecstacy!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Rigobert, why that's my Tailor!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [looking at him] Eh! blue coat, white buttons, why that's it, there is my master-piece !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Oh, this is your master-piece, is it? you're the perpetrator after all! I can't move, but it cracks—the back is gasping at this moment, I feel it!
sp.stage: [Turns round, the centre seam is open.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [admiringly.] What a fit, eh ? Wax !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Cracks, you mean; dolt!—don't you see my back's laid open!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: [aside to Javotte.] Not even a tailor—a botcher !

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Oh! that's nothing ! I've my needle and thread in my pocket—give me the coat, and I'll make it all right in a minute! It's not the fault of the sewing— that's strong enough for anything, the fault's your own—you're too strong for the sewing.
sp.stage: [Pére Bonneau heard without —" Water, oh !"]
[Brididi sits on the counter, L. H. and stitches.]

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Ah ! there's my good man, at last ! Alcide—mum !
sp.stage: Enter Bonneau at the back, with his water barrel drawn by a donkey.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Ah ! Neddy knows the door, and won't pass without stopping.

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: There's Grandpa! now for a ride! now for a ride !
sp.stage: [Runs up to the donkey.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: There, now you've kissed the donkey; I suppose my turn will come. How d'ye do, everybody ? Thêrèse not come back yet ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Not yet—I expect her every moment.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: What can she be doing at the palace ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: She couldn't tell herself! Yesterday she got a great letter, with a seal as big as a cardinal's hat; and all it said was, that Thérèse Michel was to present herself at the Palace, at Versailles, and ask for the Maitre d'Hotel.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Some wedding order, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Ay, that's it, I dare say,—or something else—

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Ay—it's that, or something else! [mysteriously.]

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Come, Alcide; don't you screw up your nose, as if you smelt mystery!—you know nothing about it, so you needn't look so wise [aside to him.] nor be so stupid.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: What does he mean ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: He means what he knows—nothing.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Well, well; we shall hear the good news by and bye—we shall all make our fortunes in good time, and retire from business ! You see I've set up my carriage already, and she'll do the same, I hope, some day.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: She's beautiful enough to ride in one, at any rate! Ma'am Bonneau, by the side of your girl, Venus would have been but a fish fag ! [sighs.]

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: There's a bit of sentiment, for a Syndic.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Couldn't you lay it on a leetle stronger ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Poor man ! poor Syndic! People think he's made of rock—I know he's as soft as butter !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Hold your chatter!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: He's strong in the arm, but weak in the head—I know his tender place, —it's in the heart!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: I'll make a tender place in your back, if you're not quiet!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [standing up.] Père Bonneau, I have the honor to solicit for Alcide Le Fort, bachelor; the hand of your daughter, Thérèse: who is married already !

sp.speaker: Marie and Bonneau.
sp.p: What's that you say? what are you talking about?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Phew ! don't listen to his nonsense?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: [to Alcide.] There's my niece,—Javotte— she's single !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [shrugs his shoulders.] She's such a shrimp !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Never mind, Alcide—when Thérèse is a widow, you may have a chance—there's plenty of time, lad.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Oh, my chance is good now !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: And Michel ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Who knows—he's been gone long enough by this time to—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Alcide ! how dare you talk in that way ? I'd recommend you not to let Thérèse hear you, that's all. She, who adores her Michel, and lives but for the hour of his return !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Why, she has never even had a letter.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: What then ? Remember where he is — at the end of the world ; a man can't write when he's at such a distance as that. Besides, did'nt we, three years ago, receive from him what was better than a letter—didn't we receive three thousand francs from St. Domingo, the sum with which Thèrése bought this fine business ? No, no, Alcide, you mustn't deceive yourself.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
Madeleine.
sp.p: Exactly, [looking towards Javotte] to take another wife.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: To take myself off.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: You, Alcide!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: I'm going to Marseilles, the place of all places for oranges, and oranges will remind me of Thèrése.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: He's going away, Brididi, give him his coat; don't let him wait for us.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: I'll just see the effect of our little surprise, and then—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Suprise, what suprise ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: There's your coat, Syndic.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Don't you see he doesn't know what he's talking about.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [aside] Poor fellow. [Aloud] Well, good folks,
I must go and fill my barrel again at the fountain.

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: Oh, grandpa, take me with you, I was promised a ride.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Come along, my little man. [Takes him in his arms.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Now, Bonneau, take care of him.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Oh, let us alone, we know what we're about, don't we, boy ? Besides, I'll answer for it, Neddy won't run away with us.] Puts Edouard on the Donkey.] Hold tight my little man. Gee up, and away we go. [Exit Bonneau, & c.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Come, Javotte, let's go and get our bouquets, or we shan't be back in time to hear Marie's secret. Good bye, Alcide, you'd better turn your eyes this way.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: Not at all—he'd rather look the other, wouldn't you Syndic? Good bye, Brididi; ah, there's nothing like a nice little tailor, after all. [Exeunt Madeleine and Javotte, 1 E.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [putting on his coat, and looking around.] How comfortable we might have been here, to be sure, we two—she and I, and nobody by ; and to think that perhaps for three years she has been a widow. Three years lost, and such a lovely creature.
sp.stage: [Sighs—Exit Alcide, pushing Brididi aside, who is going also.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Psit, psit, Brididi, is there any one within hearing ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Not a soul.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [mysteriously] Come here, Brididi. I dreamt a dream last night, and this morning I have been reading in the book of dreams, and that has given me again the numbers, twenty-three, forty five, fifteen, and seventy.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Your old lottery numbers, eh ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: They must come up this time, and then we shall all be rich.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [aside] That's always the cry of gamblers, especially women. [aloud] But, I say, if your husband should suspect—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I will tell him all.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: That's the best way.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Yes, as soon as I have gained the prize.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Oh, not till then. [Aside] I'm afraid the confession will wait a long time. [Aloud.] You've got four numbers to come up, and all in the right order you know; you have been running after them some years now, and never caught them yet. How much am I to put in for you this time ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [with an effort] A Louis d'or. [Gives one.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Another yellow boy ! I say, the Louis d'ors must grow in your house, that you have so many to put in the lottery.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Hush, there's some one ; run along and bring me the ticket. [Brididi going] Stop, for fear of accidents, I have written the numbers down, and you've only to hand the paper to the clerk. [Gives paper.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Oh, I know them well enough, without that—I think I ought, by this time.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Twenty-three, forty-five —

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Yes, Twenty-three—forty-five.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Fifteen and seventy.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [mechanically] Fifteen and seventeen, all right! besides, they are written down. [In going out, he runs up against Baptiste, C. who enters dressed in a Coachman's Livery.] Where are you driving Mr. Coachman ? Exit Brididi, C.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Keep on your own side. Good day, Ma'am Bonneau don't you remember me ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Oh! yes, perfectly—you are M. Baptiste, formerly coachman to the Marquis de Melcy—

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: [sitting down] Ay, five years ago. Would I were now. My present place is quite unsuited to my genius and disposition. I wan't another, and I thought perhaps your daughter might hear of one.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: With whom are you now ?

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p:
With, Madame St. Prie, but she lives too quiet for me. I have been accustomed to a more bustling life. My horses have waited at the doors of concerts, balls, and theatres, while I regaled myself in style. Now I'm kept waiting outside
hospitals and alms houses. It's dismal and depresses me -it is cold, and my nose gets red.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Well, I'll speak to Thérèse for you. Leave me your address. You will find pen and ink on the counter.
sp.stage: [He goes to it and writes, meanwhile enter Gaspard at the back, picking his way with precaution, lest he should splash himself.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: What a precious place ! One ought never to venture here without stilts. Number nineteen, this must be it. But what a door ! Hang me if I attempt to go in. Holloa there ! my good woman!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [in the shop] Sir !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: It's at number nineteen, I believe, that is to say, in this house that Monsieur Victor lodges, is it not ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Monsieur Victor, oh ! yes, and a nice young gentleman he is. Poor fellow ! he lives at the top of the house, up six pair of stairs.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You do know him then ? [Coming into the Shop.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Know him, of course I do—only by sight though, for he speaks to no one. He is always decently dressed, and you'd fancy, to look at him, that he wanted for nothing, but ah: sir! in this life appearances are like thin ice, very dangerous to trust to.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Is he within ?

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: I know that voice! [Aside while writing.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No sir, I think not.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: That's a pity! I came to answer a letter he addressed to my master, the Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: [aside] The Marquis de Melcy !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Is the late Marquis's son then found at last, and in Paris ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: He has been a week and more in the mansion of his fathers.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: [advancing] I do not mistake, it is Gaspard.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Baptiste ! [aside] The devil take him! [Crosses R. H.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Here's luck! you were looking out for a situation, and can now perhaps pop into your old one. I'll leave you to talk it over, and, in the meantime, Monsieur Victor may be in again! [aside] The Marquis de Melcy's son come back, oh! how happy my good man will be.
sp.stage: [She goes out, and sits on the outside of the shop, Baptiste has been contemplating Gaspard with stupid surprise.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside.] This rogue knows too much—but luckily he's an ass, and does not know the price of a secret. [aloud.] Well, Baptiste, my fine fellow ! what are you staring at me in that stupid way for? Did you think I was dead? Do you take me for my ghost ? I am flesh and blood, you may rely upon it !

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: I am neither blind nor deaf, Master Gaspard. I heard you say that the young Marquis was installed in his father's mansion, and I see you wear his livery. You are in his service then !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Your sagacity has hit it.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: You in the Marquis's service ! why you came here five years ago, to rob him of his inheritance and his name !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: To destroy the will!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I did—I see you've a good memory.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: You didn't succeed then, in carrying it off ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I carried it off.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: And yet you couldn't effect your purpose after all!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Monsieur Baptiste, your sagacity this time is at fault. Know, sir, that I can do all that I will do. I left Paris with the document in my possession, and embarked with it for St Domingo.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Ah ! ah! where the Marquis's father, the Duke, awaited you, and in exchange for that will, was to pay you ten thousand francs. You handed him the will, and he handed you the money. Nothing could be more simple, or more agreeable.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You think so ? But it so happened, that on my arrival, I learned that the Duke was dead ! What do you say to that ? He left behind him only a daughter, the elder sister of the late Marquis—the aunt of the present.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: The Countess de Melcy, I know her. Well! of course you claimed the recompence from her.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You would have been clever enough to do that now, wouldn't you ?

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: I believe you! In half a minute.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Exactly—without knowing whether she shared the prejudices of her father, without previously ascertaining whether, instead of paying you the ten thousand francs, she would not have sent you to prison for the abstraction of the will!—as she would infallibly have done, for she found among her father's papers, a letter from the Marquis ; revealing the existence of his son! towards whom she already felt her heart yearn.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: And that yearning cost you ten thousand francs. I see it all.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You see nothing.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: You didn't lose the ten thousand francs?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Quite the reverse—I gained a hundred thousand.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Whew! And nibbled them ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I shall nibble.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: But who are they to come from ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: The young Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Whom you wanted to disinherit ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: When it answered my purpose, but I lost no time in putting him into possession of a great name, and a splendid fortune when I found it answer my purpose better. The hundred thousand francs will be paid to me on the day when the sequestration of his property is annulled, or on the day of his marriage with a rich young wife, which will take place in a week's time.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Really, you're a cleverer fellow than I took you for. I bow to my superior !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Sir you are too complimentary.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: But, stop ; how did you know where this young man was ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I didn't know. I found him !

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Found him ! but how ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Simply by wanting to find him.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Miraculous ! But what put you on the trace ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Chance ! that blind protector of the bold and skilful. The young man was in St. Domingo, and knew nothing of his noble birth; I enlightened him! I found him poor, ambitious, without a name! I made him rich, noble and contented!

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: And you count upon his gratitude ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Its stamped and in my pocket. I have him in my power.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: You're a wonderful man! May I hope for your interest in getting me my old place of coachman to the Marquis ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: It's yours already! The Marquis and his noble aunt have only just arrived in France, and the old house is scarcely mounted yet. In fact, I came here to look after a young man, who solicited the place of secretary.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: You took that trouble ? What a condescension !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I had a purpose in it—but I can't wait now—my hat. [Baptiste goes to the counter, R. H., where Gaspard put his hat — meanwhile Gaspard says aside.] The letter was signed " Victor ! " and said that the writer had been educated at the College of Beauvais—that was the college where the Marquis de Melcy—I must speak with this young man.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: [bringing his hat.] There it is, Monsieur Gaspard, I shall give my mistress warning at once. The Marquis's is the place for me, and Madame St. Prie may drive herself, if she likes.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Madame St. Prie, did you say? Baptiste, a word; you needn't mention to your mistress, that you are coming to live with the Marquis. I don't want her even to know of his being in Paris, just at present.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: Mum !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p:
[to Marie.] My good woman, I can't wait any
longer. Will you do me the favor to give Monsieur Victor this note. I have appointed him to come to me this evening— and be good enough to tell me the nearest coach-stand, for I cannot possibly wade through these sloppy streets again.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Certainly, sir. Here Baptiste—run for a coach, directly!

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: A coach! for Monsieur Gaspard!—not exactly— I'll have the honor of driving him myself! My mistress will be an hour longer, at the very least; and in the meantime, her coachman and her horses will be proud to be at his service.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Sir, your offer is too tempting to be refused—but I must be home in ten minutes.

sp.speaker: Baptiste.
sp.p: In seven—I drive my horses, as you do your affairs. I smash now and then, to be sure, but I always arrive in time.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Monsieur Baptiste, I always arrive in time, and never smash. You're a numskull!
sp.stage: [Exit Gaspard and Baptiste, c.
Enter Alcide, Brididi and Cabri, followed by Madeleine, Javotte and the other Market Women and Millers, c., and lastly a small band of Musicians.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: At last, that fine gentleman's gone, and we may come in. Now, Marie ; where shall we place ourselves ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Come in! come in, all of you ! [to Musicians.] You stand opposite the door, and wait the signal. [to Cabri who carries a new signboard, covered with a cloth.] You here! Thérèse will be home in a few minutas, and must find us all at our posts.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
