sp.p: Well, but Marie; let us into the secret now, at any rate.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Well then—but mum! I don't want my good man, Bonneau, to hear—the suprise is for him, as well as Thérèse— and he'll be back in a minute, so watch for him, and listen!

sp.speaker: 1st verse.
sp.l: Listen well to me, friends,
A secret I've to tell, 'tis true—
You'll as happy be friends,
As though the good had come to you !
But before repeating
The joyful news I now withhold,
Pardon my entreating,
Silence until I'd have it told;
Not a word you'll say then,
A secret's gone when once its known,
Keep mine well to day then,
To-morrow perchance you'll have your own.
No, not a word, no not a word,
To-morrow perchance you'll have your own :
No, not a word, no not a word,
To-morrow perchance you'll have your own.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Not a word we'll say then,
A secret's gone when once its known ;
We'll keep yours to day then,
To-morrow perchance 'twill be our own!
No, not a word, no not a word,
The secret we'll keep as if our own.

sp.speaker: 2nd verse.
sp.l: Well, then you must know, friends,
The glad surprise I've here prepared ;
Will make your bosoms glow, friends,
For pleasure's doubled when its shared.
Yet I can't help shrinking—
Temptation's great, resistance small,
On second thoughts I'm thinking —
I'd much better not divulge at all;
Not a word I'll say then,
A secret's gone when once its known ;
I'll keep mine to day then,
To-morrow perchance 'twill be your own !
No, not a word, no not a word,
To-morrow perchance 'twill be your own.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Not a word she'll say then.
A secret's gone, when once its known ;
She'll keep hers to day then,
To-morrow perchance 'twill be our own—
No not a word, no not a word, &c. &c. &c.

div.stage: After Song, enter Bonneau, with Edouard in his arms, C.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Holloa! holloa ! What's all this ? Is the Market in a state of siege ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Its a little surprise, my dear Bonneau ! you'll know what it is as soon as Thérèse comes.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [who has been looking out at the back] She iscome ! there she is, getting out of the Diligence, now; Pére Bonneau, open your eyes, but stay ! you've no bouquet! you must have a bouquet to present to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Well, and what do you call this? [points to Edouard] This is the sweetest bouquet for a mother.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Now Syndic! off with the covering, and unveil the mystery.
sp.stage: Alcide takes off the covering from the sign, on which is seen the Arms of France in gold, and under them this inscription: — "Thérèse Michel, Fruiterer to his Majesty."

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: What's that? Thérèse Michel, Fruiterer to His Majesty!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: What do you say to that, old man ? she has been for her diploma to Versailles, and here she comes. Strike up music! [Music — Enter Thérèse, she throws off her cloak, and appears in a gala dress of a Market Woman. She embraces Bonneau, Marie and Madeleine, the rest present their bouquets.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Long live Thérèse, Fruiterer to the Court!

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: Long live Mamma, Fruiterer to the Court.
sp.stage: [Runs to Thérèse who kisses him.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Father—mother—friends—you know all then !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: We've only just heard it.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: The secret was well kept, for a good reason—nobody knew it.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Except Alcide Le Fort, and his modesty no doubt prevented him from speaking; for you must know friends, that it is to him I owe this unexpected good fortune ; it was he who begged this privilege for me.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Alcide!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Which only proves that some people have credit at Court, and don't forget their friends on occasion. Up with the sign boys. [They take the sign out and put it up.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: [to Javotte] What an angel of a man, eh !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: And how am I to thank him, I owe him so much—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: That you must pay him directly. Never run in debt my child, especially with the men ; they so seldom do anything to merit gratitude, that women should be careful not to dishearten them.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: You are right mother, and as I have kept out of debt so long, I won't begin now. Alcide, I pay cash down— [offering her cheek]—Give me a receipt ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Eh ! Thérèse what do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Pretty little innocent, does'nt understand when a pretty woman says—kiss me!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: What really ? [Crosses to Thérèse.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [laughing] Unless you object!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Object! [kisses her] Soft as a peach ! T'other side please ! [kisses the other cheek] Hard as a rock ! Play up music !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [sitting down] No no, that's quite noise enough; the journey, the excitement, the flowers, the music, confuse my head too much. [Alcide motions the Musicians to withdraw.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Well, well, we'll adjourn the fete till to night, and then we'll return to it with spirit. Come girls! one cheer and good bye!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Long live Thérèse ! Fruiterer to the Court!
sp.stage: [Exeunt Madeleine and the Market Women.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: My darling Thérèse, your happiness is now complete, indeed.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Oh ! yes—as far as—[sighs and looks at Edouard]

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Why that sigh, Thérèse ? It's ungrateful at such a moment.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: It is—it is—but it was involuntary. I ought to be happy, yet sadness fills my heart—a vague presentiment steals into my breast, I know not of what. [Enter Victor, C.] This morning in getting into the coach, I discovered I had lost the little silver heart, given me by dear, dear Michel, on our wedding day.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: What nonsense! you are rich enough now to replace it by two of gold, if you like.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: No gold can replace that, for it contained a lock of his hair—the only thing I had belonging to him!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [aside.] What stuff, about a lock of hair! [aloud] Well, don't fidget about it, and I will send the Town Crier after it, but it shall be found.
sp.stage: [Victor now advances to Thérèse, and presents a silver heart. He is dressed like a gentleman, but very simply.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: It was you then, madam, to whom this heart belonged? I am delighted to be able to restore it to you.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Monsieur Victor!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Oh, thanks, Monsieur Victor, thanks. I don't know how to thank you sufficiently. [Kisses it.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: She wouldn't do all that for a lock of my hair! How she loves that confounded Michel! I can't stand by patiently and see it. [Strikes a chair, which falls in pieces.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Holloa, holloa! Take care of the property, young man.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: He's going into the upholstery line, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Monsieur Victor, you have made me as happy as a Queen.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [to Victor.] And I have good news for you neighbour—some one has been inquiring for you, and left this little note. You are to be at the Marquis de Melcy's this very day.
sp.stage: [Gives him the note.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: What's that you say, Marie ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I say that which will make you jump for joy, too, old man. The young Marquis, whom you have so long been expecting, is arrived at last, and is now in the house of his father.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I tell you, he has just arrived from St. Domingo.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: St. Domingo! Where my Michel is!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [aside] Michel again, nothing but Michel. I can't stand it, I'll go home and smash all the crockery.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Where are you off too in such a hurry, Syndic ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: To pack up.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Nonsense, don't be a noodle !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: I shall be, if I stop here. Look there.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: What, at the young man ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: No, at your daughter. I'll pack up and be off. [Going, he runs against Brididi, w ho enters C. Seizes him and throws him into the the air] Stand out of the way.
sp.stage: [Exit C. and L. H.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Heyday, what's the matter with the Syndic ? Père Bonneau, I've been looking for you; here's a man brought a letter from your old village; you weren't at home, and so I brought him along with me.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: From the village, let's have a look at him.
sp.stage: [Exit with Brididi C. and off L. H.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [who with Thérèse has been talking to Victor.] Mind you're punctual, Monsieur Victor.
sp.stage: [Goes to Counter L. H. and arranges flowers.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: And pray let us know your success.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Oh! how gladly shall I return to announce it. The poverty I have struggled to conceal, is not the consequence of a fault, nor of idleness. I have sought work everywhere, but it not easy for a gentleman to find work that may not disgrace him.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: You are then, of gentle birth ?

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Not so; but I am a gentleman by education. A worthy man, whose name I never knew, placed me at the College of Beauvais, and furnished me with the means of pursuing my studies there, when suddenly my pension ceased, and I never heard of my benefactor more. Thrown thus upon the world without resources, without family, I resolved to profit by the education I received—I had became Secretary to the Count de Cremancé.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: And how did you lose the place ?

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: By having a heart that forgot my humble state—by daring to love the daughter of the Count, who loved me in return. Driven from the house like a valet, who has rubbed his master, I have since vainly sought employment, until today, when the chance of the Marquis de Melcy's accepting my services seem like a gleam of sunshine.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: May it prove so, and repay you for the happiness you have given me.
sp.stage: [Bonneau, pale and agitated, appears at back, and beckons Marie, unseen by Thérèse, who continues talking to Victor.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p:
Mercy on me! what's the matter with Bonneau ?
Can he have discovered! What has happened ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: You'll know soon enough.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: You frighten me to death.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Come, quick.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: He knows all, and I'm lost. [Exit with Bonneau C.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Our prayers will go with you, Monsieur Victor.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: They cannot fail to bring me good fortune.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: And should your hopes not be realized, come back to us, and you shall always find a home.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: [kissing her hand.] Bless you, and farewell. [Exit R.C.
sp.stage: [Exit Thérèse with Edouard into her room L. H. Marie returns, C. with a letter.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [aside.] Bonneau has discovered nothing! But how are we to bear this sad calamity ?
sp.stage: Re-enter Thérèse L. H.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Thérèse, I have something to say to you.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: What can it be ? How agitated you seem mother !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No, only just now you were speaking of a presentiment—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [gaily looking at the silver heart.] Which is gone, quite gone, and I'm as gay as a lark again. It seems as if with this had come back the certainty of Michel's speedy return.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [aside] Poor child, poor child ! How shall I break it to her! So happy about a moment ago, and now—[Aloud.] Thérèse, I—I too have a presentiment, which—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Mother, not on my account. I am in high spirits now, and this evening intend to dance with our merry neighbours at the Carnival, join their procession to the Porcherons, sup with them, sing with them, Edouard shall go with us, and we'll drink to the health of Michel, and to his speedy return.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: His return!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Yes, we shall see him soon now—I feel we shall.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Thérèse, you're in too high spirits—don't! You make me feel I don't know how, for—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [looking earnestly at her.] My dear mother, you tremble!—there's something on your mind! has anything happened to you ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: To me! No; that is yes, for all that concerns you is— You know how dearly I love you. [Kisses her on the forehead] What was I saying ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: That you had a presentiment—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Exactly. Yours came from the loss of this trinket, mine from—from—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: A dream, perhaps ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: A dream, yes, that's it. I've had a dream.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Poor mother, always dreaming. [Aside

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Yes I dreamt something last night, that I want to relate to you; come, sit down by me. [Both sit.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [taking Marie by the hand.] Oh, mother, you terrify me.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Listen, my darling, and leave your hand in mine, while I am speaking, it will help me, it will give me courage. Well, last night I dreamt of—him—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Michel!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Michel. I saw the poor fellow, there, far away, across the seas, where he went to seek his fortune, I saw him plainly, and he smiled at me from his bed of sickness.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [trembling] He was ill ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Very ill, the doctor was at his bedside.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Michel ill! dying! but what folly, it was only a dream, after all.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: That's all. Only just now, while I stood here calm, happy, suspecting nothing, your father beckoned me to see a stranger, who brought a letter addressed to you at our village, and coming from—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [with exclamation] Saint Domingo ! from Michel!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Not from Michel.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: A letter from Saint Domingo, and not from him, and you are weeping ! it was not a dream then ! Support me Heaven! Michel is dead !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I dared not conceal it from you, longer!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Dead ! Michel dead!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: It is a terrible blow, Thérèse, but think of your boy, he will give courage. I do not speak of your father, of myself, of all the friends who love you. Thérèse! Thérèse! why don't you cry? it will relieve you. [Thérèse is like one in a stupor.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Michel, dead!
sp.stage: At this moment, Edouard runs in, in great glee, L . H.

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: Mamma, Mamma, come and look ! here's such a grand carriage, just driving into the Market! Oh, do come !
sp.stage: [Thérèse's grief is loosened by the voice of her child — she looks at it a moment, then wildly clasping it to her breast exclaims:

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: My child ! my boy ! oh! I have still my boy !

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: Oh, mamma, don't cry so ! what's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Edouard—you will never, never see your—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Thérèse, Edouard is too young to feel his loss yet. Don't sadden his dear little heart!

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: Lost!—what's lost mamma ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p:
You are right, mother—I will not awaken such early sorrow in his breast. Edouard, you are now my life—for
you, for you alone, I have to live. [sobbing.] Oh! Michel! Michel!
sp.stage: [At this moment the crowd is seen pressing at the back, with the cries of "Take care !" — "Take care !" A carriage, obstructed by the crowd, enters at a walk. Michel elegantly dressed, looks out of the carriage window.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: What is all this ? Cannot a carriage pass along this abominable place?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [at the sound of his voice, raises her head.] Gracious Heaven ! that voice ! that voice ! It's he! It's Michel!
sp.stage: [A running Footman advances, and calls to the people] Footman. Make room there! Room for the carriage of the Marquis de Melcy!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: The Marquis de Melcy!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: The Marquis de Melcy !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: The Marquis de Melcy ! Oh ! then I am mad !
sp.stage: [she falls on her knees in despair, and hides her face in her hands.]

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: [kneeling.] Mamma, mamma.

div.stage: Tableau.

div.head: Act IV.
div.stage: Interior of Bonneau's House on the ground floor modestly furnished, like that of an Artizan.
In the flat an opening into a small Court Yard with rustic stables. Doors right and left. Music as the curtain rises.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [entering and speaking to some one without, R. C.] Thank you, neighbour; thank you. I only want them to amuse my little Edouard with, this evening, I'll bring you them back to-morrow. [enters and shuts the door.] Another fib! but I didn't like to own before her husband, that I was borrowing a pack of cards, to tell my fortune with. Bonneau won't be in for some time, and I will see what the cards have in store for me ; I'm determined ! [goes toward the table, R. H.] In crossing the stage, she stumbles against one of the stones in the floor, which is a little out of its place.] Good gracious ! here's this stone still out of its place ; I had forgotten it. If my husband had come home, he must have discovered it! [places the cards upon the table — returns and kneels near the displaced stone, and before fixing it, looks into the void space, for a moment.] Nothing left! no, not a sou !—and three years ago there were [shudders] oh ! I tremble to think of it ! But to-morrow it will be all right again. To-day the lottery is drawn, and I shall gain my prize to a certainty : and then I shall replace it. [she hears the door, L. H., opening, and rapidly replaces the stone — starts up and puts her foot upon it, in terror.] Who's that ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Ma'am Bonneau! Ma'am Bonneau! [at door, L. H.
sp.stage: Enter Brididi, hiding one eye under his hand

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, Ma'am Bonneau, its only me! I've just dropped in as I was passing by, to beg a drop of spring water, to bathe my eye.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [recovering herself.] Oh! is that all! what's the matter with it ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Well, to be frank with you, I can't see clearly what is the matter—perhaps you can tell me. [takes away his hand and shews his eye, red and inflamed.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Ah! my poor lad, what's this ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: It's a left hander— a left hander I gave to—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: To yourself!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: To myself, not such a fool as that—no, to somebody else, of course. I sent this left hand of mine at him, and he replied with a right hander upon my left eye, you see the consequence.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: But how comes it, Brididi, you whom I thought so quiet and so peaceable, are you a fighter then ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Oh! I can strike a blow now and then, as well as my betters, and you're welcome to one, Ma'am Bonneau.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I'm much obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: No, no, you do not understand me. I mean, it was in your service that I invested one, just now on the nose of my adversary as a small proof of my esteem, and which he has so lovingly returned on my eye. It was Cabri, who was bringing his water buckets into the Lottery Office, while I was getting your ticket, he asked me who I was buying for—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [anxiously] You did not tell him ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Not I, trust me for that! what, to a comrade of your husband's ? no, no, no, I replied boldly, that I was buying for myself.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Good lad, that was right!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Yes, but he had seen me give the Louis d'or to the clerk, and he had the impertinence to say I deserved to be taken before a Justice, as it was quite clear that such a sum of money laid out on a Lottery Ticket by one like me, could only have been stolen.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Stolen!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Now, as I knew that was false on the very face of it, I thought I'd prove it so on the face of him who had asserted it. I did so, I asked him telegraphically with my left hand, what he meant by that insinuation, and here's his reply. If you get nothing by the Lottery, Ma'am Bonneau, at all events I've got something.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Oh! don't say if, the very thought of such a possibility, would drive me crazy!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Well, its not pleasant, certainly. But after all, you've a right to do as you please with your own money.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No, Brididi, there's the misery of it—it was not mine.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Eh! not yours! What, all those Louis d'ors that
I have—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [trembling.] Hush! there's somebody in the Courtyard.
sp.stage: Bonneau appears in the Court-yard without, with his Donkey and Barrel.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Marie.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [aside with terror.] My husband!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Give me the key of the stables.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Take it, Brididi, you will find it in my work basket; my legs refuse to carry me.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: [taking the key to Bonneau.] There it is, Père Bonneau.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [unharnesses the Donkey.] Thank you, my fine fellow. [To Marie] You're surprised to see me so soon, eh? and my days work done already ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [recovering from her agitation.] True, you are much earlier than usual.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: The fact is, I have got some important business to transact; I'll tell you all about it presently.
sp.stage: [Exit into stable, R. H.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Now, Ma'am Bonneau, you'll explain, I hope, what this little affair is that I have been mixed up with; I feel rather uncomfortable, and have certain misgivings that I gave Cabri a tap on the nose that he was not entitled to.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Oh, Brididi, I have been to blame, greatly to blame, but still not so much as you suppose.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: As I suppose ! Oh, I had no particular suppositions ; at any rate, no dishonourable ones. It is not very likely that you've been stopping the Diligence at your time of life, and robbing the passengers—you are not a highwayman, I know.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: When I said the gold was not mine, I didn't exactly mean that—I had a right to a share of it after all, for what belongs to my husband belongs to me.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Oh, its only a little domestic matter, is it! Oh, then, Cabri may keep his tap on the nose; but I forgot—he returned it to me.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I can't think why my husband should have made a mystery of his little fortune to me; I had no suspicion of anything of the kind till three years ago, when we moved into this house to be near Thérèse. Late one night, Bonneau believing me to be asleep, rose gently from the bed, and through my half closed eyes I saw him take out of one of the water buckets a small canvas bag, which seemed very heavy, and with it he passed out of the next room into this. I followed him; saw him lift up one of these squares, and after digging in the ground underneath with his knife, he hid the bag carefully away, and closed the square over it. When he returned, I still feigned to be asleep, but I lay awake, torturing myself with all sorts of absurd suspicions. In the morning, while Bonneau was gone to work, I raised the stone, opened the bag, and found it full of gold.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: How terrible ! No, I mean how pleasant!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p:
You see, Brididi, I had always from a girl a presentiment that I should gain a fortune in the lottery; but, in my miserable existence, the chance had never occurred of my being
able to buy a ticket. But now that chance was ready to my hand. I struggled against it for weeks, but alas! I struggled in vain, for I fell at last.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: That's where you got wrong.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I took one Louis d'or—having lost that, you may easilly suppose I risked another, in the hope of getting it back, and so I have gone on, losing and losing, until the last Louis d'or that the bag contained is now gone, and if the prize does not come up this time, all is over. If despair and shame do not kill me, my husband will.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Nay, nay ! don't talk in that way, Ma'am Bonneau. You must win, you shall win; you've got excellent numbers— the clerk told me so, and he ought to know.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: But you haven't given me my ticket.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: That's true. [Taking ticket from his pocket.] There are your numbers—there are the respectable old gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [reading] Yes, that's right—twenty-three, forty five,

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Twenty-three, forty-five

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Fifteen and seventy

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Yes, fifteen and seventeen, that's it. I'll run to the office, and bring you the list of prizes as they come up. Oh here's Thérèse.
sp.stage: [Going to door L. H. meets Thérèse, who puts her cloak upon the back of a chair. As Thérèse enters, Brididi exits.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: That's right, child, you have done well to come and see us. Its not good to be alone, when one's sad.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Yes, I came to—What did I come for ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: You have something perhaps to tell me ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: No. no ! I left home without motive, without object, simply because I could not rest quiet. I walked on listlessly, till I found myself opposite the little shed where my father lived when we first came to join him in Paris.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Ah ! in that happy Rue de l'Echelle ; where we were living when Michel sent you the three thousand francs.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: The last token we had of his existence. I wished to see that house again and still more, the house which faced it, and which used to be sad and silent as a tomb, but which is now open to all the world; full of life and movement. As I gazed on it I forgot my grief—for I had a hope, a strong and fervent hope—but I waited a long time, and he did not return.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Return! why who on earth did you expect ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: No one, no one at all, mother—I have no one to expect, now! and yet were I to tell you the idea which pursues me—an idea which, though I cannot believe in it, nevertheless incessantly comes back upon me—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: What idea, Therese? what is it?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: That Michel is not dead !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Poor child! poor child !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Tell me, mother! Michel never spoke of his family to us, did he ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: His family! you know that he had none; he has told us a hundred times, that he was a foundling.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Yes! educated by charity in a college where he served as an example to the other pupils, because he was more diligent, because he had more talent, 'Twas that very superiority which gave him his ambitious notions.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Yes! he had always an idea in his head that he was born for some higher condition.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: And why should he not be ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Thérèse, I do not understand you ! This very day you receive the certificate of your husband's death, and yet you speak of him as if he were still alive.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Mother, I have already told you that the announcement of his death, was no proof to me.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No proof!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: No. You assert that I have lost him, I answer, that I have seen him.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Seen him!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: See him still. [Sits by the table, R. H.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [aside] Her poor head is wandering !
sp.stage: [Sits at table at work, L. H.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [taking up the cards mechanically.] There are those who pretend that our destiny is written in the cards! Who read them like a book, read there the mysteries of the future, the secrets of the past. Should it be true! [arranges the card] I wonder how they place them.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: What is she about? [rises the better to see, then going towards Thérèse] Oh! that's not the way, child !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Do you know how, then ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Yes, just a little.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: And you believe in the cards, do you not ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Of course I do. They often shew us what we wish for.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Then let us see if they will not shew me—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Hush ! your father's there, and he can't bear cards. He says that consulting them is flying in the face of Providence.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: No matter,—at any price I must discover—Sit down, dear mother; you won't be a moment—I intreat you!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No, no; stay where you are, and I'll shew you. If your father comes he won't scold you. Now, shuffle the cards.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Must I choose one ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No, never do that! you must take them as they come.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [shuffling the cards] Ay, that's better—it leaves it to chance.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p:
Of course! chance is everything. Now, place them
in a half circle. [aside] I shall find out so, whether I am to get the prize.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: What next ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Count the cards one by one, till I stop you. [Thérèse counts — each time placing her finger on the card —Marie stops her] That will do! Its a young man.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Yes, the Knave of Hearts! [aside] That's Michel!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [aside] That's Brididi! [aloud] Go on—very well- there ! a letter!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [aside] To contradict the one I received to-day !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [aside] That letter contains the list of prizes. [aloud] Go on again—stop ! A great piece of news!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Joyful news, mother ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [counting with her] Go on—go on—Ah ! [stopping her and uttering a cry of joy.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Do you see that my child ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: How you tremble!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: With joy, dear ! with joy ! Do you see that card— the Nine of Clubs! The Nine!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: And that means—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Money—heaps of money—a fortune !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [rising] Oh !—mother ! you talk to me of money, when I am thinking only of my husband !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Not a word—here's some one! [hiding the cards.
sp.stage: Enter Alcide—Madeleine following, L. H.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: May I come in ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: You are in !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Shall I go out again, and knock first?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No —our door is always open to friends, and the Syndic is one of them.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: I should think so, and Madeleine is another—come in, Madeleine. [aside.] I hope soon to be something more, now that the lovely Thérèse is a widow! I needn't pack up.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: What brings you here ?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Well, I can't say that we absolutely came to see you, Marie ; old friend as you are. Our visit was to Thérèse— not having found her at her own house, we thought she might be here.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Yes, our visit was to Thérèse.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: To me, Alcide; for what?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: To spare you, if possible the annoyance of receiving the whole market. As soon as the girls heard of your misfortune, they were all coming down in a body, to—to—

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: To congratulate you.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [shocked] To congratulate her!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: What are you saying ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: No, no ; I don't mean that—I mean to condole. Did I say "congratulate ? That's because I'm an ass—I only meant that all the girls were—and so am I—I'm sure —I needn't—

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: That'll do—you'll only make it worse. The fact is, Thérèse, we had another object; we come commissioned from the market—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Not now, kind friends—another time.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Unfortunately no other time will do. Its a mere form— we know it is impossihle for you to accept the honour at such a time, but it is our duty to offer you the privilege of presenting the bouquet!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Bouquet! what bouquet?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: You know our custom in the market—on all public occasions—births,—marriages,—fetes, we have the right by patent, to present ourselves in our holyday clothes, at all the great houses, with our eloquence and our flowers! His Majesty himself has listened to our harangues before now—and so as the son of a grand Marquis has been restored to the house of his fathers, and come into possession of his property ; we have decided that it would be a pretty little compliment to ofter him the bouquet of congratulation !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: And as Syndic of the Market, I head the procession!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: But my dear friends, you know Thérèse has always refused to join in such ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: What did I say Madeleine? why, even when we went to the King himself you know she would'nt go with us ! It's a likely joke, that after that, she would give the preference to the Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: To the Marquis de Melcy, did you say ? is it to him you are going to present the bouquet ?

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Yes, to shew our delight at his return.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Exactly, our frantic delight. No one ever heard of him before, but that does'nt matter—our delight's just as great, and the compliment costs us nothing.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [to herself] To the Marquis de Melcy!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: You refuse, of course ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: I accept!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Wait for me a moment, and I'll go with you.
sp.stage: [Getting her Cloak.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: But my child—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [resolutely] It is my duty, it is my right! Am I not now at the head of the Market ? Alcide, come and help me prepare the bouquet ! [to Madeleine] In ten minutes I will meet you here. Come Alcide.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [offering his arm] Always at your service !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [to Thérèse, who is putting on her cloak] Thérèse, do you know where you are going ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Yes, to the Marquis de Melcy's! [to herself] I wished to see him once more—I will see him !
sp.stage: [Exit with Alcide. door L. H.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: She's a girl after my own heart! I'll run for Javotte meantime, and be back to meet her in five minutes.
sp.stage: [Exit door, L. H.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I can't make it out! Thérèse accept on such a day ! the first day of her mourning! Oh, her grief must have turned her head!
sp.stage: Enter Bonneau, from Stable C.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Marie, was'nt that Thérèse I saw just now, tripping along with Alcide, the Syndic ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: It was indeed!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Going where ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: To present a bouquet to the new Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: To the son of my old protector! for he is so!—I have made every inquiry, and there's no doubt as to the fact. Ah, ah ! they are going to carry him a bouquet, are they ? I flatter myself I have one for him that will beat theirs into fits, and be twice as well received. Marie, go and get my Sunday coat, [she goes to chest of drawers, L. H.] I've been and got shaved in honor of the occasion. Kiss me Marie, and you'll ascertain the fact. [Offers his cheek.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Why Bonneau, what has put you in such tip-top spirits to-day ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Do you want to know ? then I'll tell you.—I've had a two hundred pound weight upon my breast for years, and now its removed. That's my state. For five years I have been labouring under the oppression, and now I breathe again.—If it wasn't for the sorrow of our darling daughter, I'm so happy, I could sing songs, and cut capers like a child.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: But what's it all about ? one would think you had gained a prize in the Lottery ?
sp.stage: [Takes his coat off and puts it on chair.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Lottery indeed! I gain a prize every time it's drawn.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: You do ? How, how

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: By never putting into it. That's the way all honest folks should win. Lottery indeed! Ah, Marie ! when I pass by the office, and see the crowd of women there, carrying to that Grumbling House the hard earnings of their husband's toil, the sweat of their brows, the price of their children's bread, and all to satisfy their wretched passion for unholy gain, I say to myself, shame be upon their heads! they are bad wives, and worse mothers! Heaven can never smile upon their works.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [with emotion] Bonneau, tell me, tell me, what was it made you so happy, when you came in ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: First give me my holiday clothes! I'm going to court ! In state! my white cravat, my new waistcoat!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: What for ? what for ? The man will drive me crazy!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Get me my cravat, and I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I'll not budge an inch, till I hear!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Well, then—[sits down.]—while you put on my cravat you shall hear—You must know, that on the very day of his death, the old Marquis de Melcy deposited with me a large sum of money; all in gold.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: In gold!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: What's the matter with you ? Its as true as I sit here ! That gold I was to place into the hands of his son—but his son never came! Nevertheless, my duty was simple—I had to keep the money till the young Marquis appeared to claim it— ay, and I'd have kept the two hundred Lonis d'ors till doomsday, if—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Were there so many ? Two hundred Louis! here !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Oh! don't be alarmed—not only were here, but are here still, untouched ! Two hundred Louis d'ors within a yard of our feet ! That's the weight I've had upon my breast so long. I have never dared mention it to a living soul—not even to you, Marie—my wife—never had the courage to look into the hiding-place, where I concealed it. But, heyday! Marie!—how's this ? you turn pale!—what's the matter with you, are you ill ? [rising]

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [with a choking voice] No—not ill—and yet I feel somewhat—

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: I understand—the mere thought of such a sum of money concealed in our poor dwelling, and we responsible, has upset your nerves; but compose yourself—the danger is over now—for this very day, this very hour, I am going to restore it, intact. Oh ! for that matter, rather than have used a sou of it, we would all have starved!—eh, Marie? Money that does not belong to us, is sacred. We have no right to touch it; not even to buy a loaf of bread !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [aside and supporting herself with difficulty] My heart dies within me!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [gaily] Marie, dear ; you never saw two hundred Louis d'ors all in gold, I know; wait a bit, and I'll make your eyes start out of your head with pleasure.
sp.stage: [takes a knife from his pocket and kneels at the stone.]

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [with an effort] Bonneau !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: There it is under that square.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [aside] Would that I were dead!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p:
[stopping in front of stone] Eh! how very odd— one would fancy that the stone had been moved—I'll
hanged if I don't begin to tremble myself! [wiping his forehead] Whew ! oh! I must, I must know my fate a once!
sp.stage: He is about to raise the stone, when Brididi enters briskly, L. H.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Victory! ma'am Bonneau, victory ! we've won!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [who has followed with intense anxiety all the movements of her husband, utters a cry of joy] Ah! won d'ye say ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [rising but remaining in the same place.] Won What?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Oh! yes, I may tell all now! I've just come from the drawing.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [trying to understand]. What is it he's talking about ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: I've just come from the drawing of the lottery. Embrace me, Ma'am Bonneau. Embrace me, Père Bonneau. The numbers have come up right, and have brought seventy thousand times the amount of the stake.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [doubting still, and looking by turns at the floor and at his wife.] What! can it be possible! No, no, she never could have been capable—

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [mastering her joy.] But are you sure—quite sure ?

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Of course, I am, here's the list. [Kneeling to Marie. Twelve was the first number—but that's not yours. Here are the others; look yourself. Twenty-three.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [takes the ticket from her pocket, and compares each number, as he reads it, with increased agitation.] Twenty-three.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Forty-five!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Forty- five!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Fifteen!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Fifteen!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: And seventeen!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [utters a cry of despair.] Ah!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: What's the matter ? Seventeen, I say.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: It should be seventy. Lost! all's lost!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [becoming aware of the whole truth.] Ah ! I see it now;
I understand—the money for the lottery has been stolen from me.
sp.stage: [He hastily tears up the stone during which time Madeleine enters with Javotte R. H.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Here we are, ready to start! Where's Thérèse ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [stands terrified before the vacant space.] Gone! all gone! Robbed, basely robbed! Accursed lottery!

sp.speaker: Madeliene.
sp.p: Lottery!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: That has brought this disgrace upon me. My treasure stolen, and the thief—

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: [seizing Brididi.] Is here!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Brididi!

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: Me!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Wretch ! [Lifts a chair, as if to strike him.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Brididi! Oh, no !

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Père Bonneau, look in his face, and read deceit and treachery there. But I've found him out—Cabri told me all; Cabri saw him put down the Louis d'or for the ticket, with his own hand. Cabri made him acknowledge on the spot, that the gold was his own, and the clerk said it was not the first, by dozens, he had bought. He has robbed you for years, Père Bonneau, and deserves the Galleys.

sp.speaker: Brididi.
sp.p: And Marie is silent!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [goes to Brididi.] Brididi, I have done with you for ever ! I did love, now I detest you. The viper who would sting the hand of his benefactor, should be spurned beneath one's feet, Brididi, you've broken my heart.
sp.stage: [Bursts into tears.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: The hand of justice shall at once— [Going.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Hold ! hold, for mercy's sake, Bonneau! I cannot bear this. He is not the culprit.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [in a fury.] Then who—who ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [falling on her knees.] Your wretched wife !

div.stage: Tableau.

div.head: Act V.
div.stage: A Splendid Saloon in the Style of Louis XV., Magnificently Furnished.
Three centre doors opening into another apartment, but closed commencement of the Act. Doors on each side.
Dubois, Lacqueys and Tradesmen, discovered waiting.
Enter Gaspard, R. H. in Full Livery.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p:
[insolently] So gentlemen, you have come to hear how we are satisfied with your goods, Monsieur Durand the furniture you have had the execrable taste to send in, for the lower rooms belongs to the past century, you must take it all away, and send us something more in the Spirit of the Age we live in. [Durand Bows] Monsieur Birman, your carriage is not bad, but it might be more elegant. Let us have one, fit for a Royal Duke. [Birman Bows] Monsieur Rigaud, your State Liveries are fair, very fair ; but the goldlace is too skimping— they should be basted, literally basted with bullion. As for you du Lambert, I think you must have been mad, to send us Norman horses ! We must have nothing but English, and thorough bred. Remember we bear one of the great names of France, and must not be treated like a parvenus. You will send in your
bills to me, and I shall pay them only when I am satisfied, quite satisfied with you. [Tradesmen bow and exeunt, L . H.

And now lacqueys, lend me your ears. Yesterday you waited at table with a carelessness that horrified me. If we had been in St. Domingo, I should have had you all whipped like Negroes, But as, unfortunately we are denied those luxuries here, and have only the right of kicking such fellows out of doors, rely on it I shall exercise that right, and effectually, if it occurs again. Now, Chocolate ! [Dubois brings Chocolate on a handsome salver] Chair! [Another lacquey wheels forward a chair. Gaspard seats himself, and begins to take the Chocolate] Letters! Cards! [Dubois presents them in his hand] Salver, Dolt! [Dubois places them on a salver, Gaspard takes the letters, aside] What have we here ? perfumed paper, armorial seals, aristocratic illegibility. There's nothing here to make one anxious— mere invitations, I dare say; for my young Marquis is progressing rapidly. It is astonishing how well he asserts his dignity ! [aloud] You may present these letters to the Marquis! [places them back on the salver, a visiting card falls] Pick it up! [Dubois picks it up, and offers it with his hand] Salver ! [Dubois puts it on the Salver, Gaspard looks carelessly on the card, and then starts up] Madame St. Prie, the unacknowledged wife of the late Marquis, and the mother of—she may derange my plans ! [aloud] What does Madame St. Prie want?

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: To see the Marquis, she said she would call later in the day.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: If I am absent when she calls, you will beg her to call again—if I am at home, shew her into me—but to me alone, you understand. I hear a carriage—it's the Marquis take these away.
sp.stage: [Dubois removes the Chocolate. Exeunt R. H.
Enter Michel, door L. H.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [impatiently] Where's the Countess ? in her room ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Not at this moment, her ladyship is not in the house; she ordered her carriage to the Count de Cremancé.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: To the Count de Cremancé, I thought as much !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Your lordship seems annoyed! Has the Minister raised any difficulties in the way of removing the sequestration from your property ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Oh! all difficulties disappear before the influence of the Count de Cremancé, and I have just learned that he looks upon me already as his son-in-law. The Countess, my noble aunt, has I find arranged a marriage between his daughter and myself, and that too, without doing me the honor to consult me.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Ay, ay, that's something like an aunt! She's an invaluable lady.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: As if I were to be disposed of in that manner. Not even my consent asked.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Why should it be ? Isn't it better as it is ? Your aunt is a woman of the world, and fearing some difficulty in getting your consent, does without it. Mademoiselle de Cremancé is a charming person—I remarked her at Versailles. She has a dowry of a million, and an influential family. Where could you find a better match ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Gaspard, you are mad. That my aunt should contemplate such a marriage, I can understand; but you ! You know perfectly well that I cannot accept the hand of Mademoiselle de Cremancé. You know that I cannot marry.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [after a pause, slowly takes out a paper, which he presents.] Will the Marquis de Melcy be good enough to pay me this small account of one hundred thousand francs ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: You are joking!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I am serious.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Serious!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: As death.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: You pledged your word never to demand that sum until I came into possession of my father's property.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Decidedly. And you pledged yours to abstain from saying or doing anything that could interfere with this payment. If, therefore, you refuse the splendid alliance now offered you, it must be because you have some other still more splendid resource ; in that case, you can pay me—pay me !

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Marry Mademoiselle de Cremancé! I! Why, madman, have you forgotten the history I gave you of my past life ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Your past life ended, when your present began. It was washed away in the waves from which I rescued you ; you, the last scion of an ancient family—but for me, engulphed in the depths of the ocean. I found you poor, friendless, helpless. I made you rich, noble, powerful. [Aside.] The mere turn of a pen effected the miracle. [Aloud.] In consideration thereof, and in the gratitude of your heart, you signed this little agreement. I have waited patiently, because you had nothing to give. Even yesterday, your possessions were doubtful ; but now that it rests but with yourself to remove the sequestration—now that a handsome wife, with a million of money, is offered to you—I cannot permit this little debt of a hundred thousand francs to stand over—it would be my ruin. Marquis, I hate to name unpleasant alternatives, but you must either marry or pay.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Gaspard, you know it cannot be—you know that I am married to another.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p:
Not at all. Michel, the poor devil who battled in vain with the waves was married, but he is dead, drowned,
gone for ever—at the bottom of the sea. Forget him, and cry, "Long live the young Marquis de Melcy Long live the future husband of Mademoiselle de Cremancé!"

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Gaspard, hear me. Thérèse is still my wife, and no earthly power can separate us.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: But if you should be free!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Free ! Heavens, can it be ? Thérèse dead!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Or married—its the same thing.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Married ! What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I mean that Thérèse is a widow, and she knows it.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Knows it!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Unless she is again a wife. I sent her the certificate of your death myself, drawn up in due form, so there can be no mistake. She has had time to shed a tear over your memory, and make your successor a happy man.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: You dared to do this ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I dare do anything that answers my purpose—that answered it. Besides, it was for her good! Think of her situation—neither wife nor widow! It was cruel! and I consider I was doing a good action, in relieving her from it.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [in an under tone.] Wretched man, do you know what you have done ? You have committed a forgery!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Exactly. And do you suppose I mean to do it gratis ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Ruffian!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Silence!—some one comes.
sp.stage: Enter Dubois, L. H.

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: There is a person wishes to speak with his Lordship —he says he comes with a message from the late Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: What does this mean ?—I will see the man myself first.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Gaspard, remain where you are! Dubois, let him come in !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: But I had better—

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: I will have it so !
Dubois shows in Bonneau, L. H.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Marquis—I—I—that is, my commission—forgive me—I wish to speak, and can't—for you see, when a man wishes to weep, and swallows his tears—it stifles him somewhat— but it will be over directly.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [seating himself.] Take your time, my good man! you would speak to me of my father, and I honor your emotion.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p:
Oh! Marquis, I have indeed reason enough to be agitated. The last time I was in this room, your honored father sat in that very chair where you now sit—my heart then was
light —to-day it is heavy with sorrow ! Then I brought him back his pocket book, which I had found, with an immense sum of money in it.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: An act which did you honor.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: It was my duty, as it is now my duty to speak to you of the deposit of two hundred Louis d'ors, which, as you doubtless know, your noble father placed in my charge.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And which you now bring with you. [aside.] That man is the incarnation of stupidity !—he lives a life of restitution!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Alas ! no—I have it no longer—and yet I had concealed it carefully under the floor of my house. I had told no one, not even my wife, of its existence ! every morning as I went to my work, I said to myself—"the young Marquis may return when he likes, his money is there!"—and to-day I was so happy to think that he was come back, and that, in spite of all the days of pinching poverty we had passed through, while that gold was in the house; yet that the treasure had been held sacred—when—just now—on going to remove it, to bring to you with pride and joy, 'twas gone—gone—there was nothing left!
sp.stage: [covers his face with his hands.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: You have been robbed!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: No, Marquis, I dare not let you suppose that—it might cast a slur upon my neighbours. 'Twas no robbery, 'twas an error.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside.] An error ! A mild form of the disease.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Yes, an error; and the culprit was my wife—my own wife—whom I have left at home almost out of her mind, because the money which she thought was ours, proves to have belonged to another. 'Twas my fault, it was indeed! I ought not to have concealed the sacred deposit from her. This, Marquis, is my story—I can scarcely ask you to believe it.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside.] I should think not!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Though were your father living, who knew me well, he would at once have taken the word of Père Bonneau, for ten times that amount.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [startled] Père Bonneau ! of Clermont Ferrand ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Yes, I am well known in the neighbourhood. But you look kindly at me—you believe in me! Oh, Marquis! my heart thanks you, my tongue cannot. And mind, I came here to tell you of my debt. To tell you it shall be paid— every sou of it—but you must wait some time—for two hundred Louis d'ors is a debt which will take a deal of water to wash out.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [has seized a pen, and rapidly written a few words on a paper, which he presents in agitation to Bonneau.] There! there—take that.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: I beg pardon, I can't read, but if this is an agreement you wish me to sign, give me the pen, and I will make my mark.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: No, Père Bonneau; it is not an agreement, it is a receipt.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: No, no, it can't be done so. It's all very well for you to say you are no longer my creditor, but that does not make me less your debtor—my conscience won't suffer that. You shall be paid. All my family will work for me. Oh! if my son-in-law were alive, he would help me, for he was a fine hearted fellow they tell me. But my daughter, Thérèse, his widow, will come to my assistance. She will sell everything, rather than suffer dishonour to fall upon her father.
sp.stage: [carriage heard at the back.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Thérèse, —your daughter—is—here—in Paris !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Yes Marquis, she's the Fruiterer to the Court

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside] I must put an end to this! [aloud] The Countess, your lordship's aunt, is returned, you wished to speak with her ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: I'm gone—Marquis, I shall never forget your generosity—though I don't accept it, I am not the less grateful. But we all have our little notions you know, and my pride revolts! [kisses his hand] But I shall never forget it! If I've tears in my eyes now, they are tears of joy. [Exit door, L. H.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: You heard what he said ? [Joyfully.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Distinctly. Your father-in-law is as honest as he is ignorant. Luckily he does not know you—if he had ever seen you before, your unguarded manner must have led to your discovery, to a certainty.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: And Thérèse, whom you supposed dead, or married, is alive ! Thérèse is here! near me, in Paris!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside] Where she'll not be long! [aloud] And what then ? how can that interest you! There can be now nothing in common between you! You can give her your custom, if you like, but that's all. They're a very interesting family, and I'll see that they make a good thing of it.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Gaspard! do you take me for a villain ? Do you think that I will sully my lips with perjury, my life with infamy ? No! I will not disown the woman whom, in the face of Heaven, I have named my wife! I will not repose in the luxury of wealth, while she is weeping desolate in poverty! I will not check the yearnings of my heart, nor thrust my love from out of it! [Crosses to R.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Very well, then, avow all to your aristocratic aunt. The Countess will be flattered to see the blood of the de Melcy's flowing in a water carriers bucket.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Flattered or not, she must hear the truth! Even family pride must bend before necessity!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p:
Your brains are wandering, Marquis! This is downright folly! Don't you perceive, that no sooner does your proud aunt hear of this degrading marriage, than she
declares it null, in the sight of the law ? for you contracted it as a foundling, and under age ! Such an act is not binding upon the Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: But it is binding upon Georges Michel, who bears the title, and can only be annulled with his consent!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: His consent! Poor fellow, he's in a dream!—but I must wake him. Oppose the Countess she will renounce you! This house is hers—it has been yours only by her courtesy—the sequestration of your property will be confirmed, and you will sink again into that misery from which I dragged you : rendered deeper, blacker, by the remembrance of the brilliant position you have lost.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: I care not—poverty, with all its terrors, is not so terrible as infamy!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Um ! you think not ? Well that's a matter of opinion, after all. But at any rate, you will agree with me in this—that a fortune and a title are better than the Galleys.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: The Galleys!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Don't you see that your fastidious scruples send you there headlong. You thwart the Countess—good! A lawsuit follows,—an endless suit. Lawyers are damnable ferrets— they poke their noses everywhere—and they will soon discover the forged certificate of your death, inscribed in the parish books.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: That forgery was yours!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: It was, I admit ; and you were my accomplice !

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Where is the Judge who will believe otherwise ? Have I not the agreement to shew, signed by yourself; giving me one hundred thousand francs, if, by my means, you obtained possession of your name and fortune ? One hundred thousand francs!—the sum's enormous! But forgery is not bought for a trifle—and when a man pays so handsomely, he generally knows the value of what he is paying for. You will of course deny, but your verbal denial will not stand against your written accusal. [holds up the agreement.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: And you will dare to assert—

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: That we were accomplices ? Certainly. I told you I dared do anything that suited my purpose. And since you force me to it, I will speak out plainly. It is better we should understand each other at once. From this moment we change places—you are no longer what you were. I am the master here, not you ; so think well before you act. Henceforth you neither know Père Bonneau nor Thérèse, his daughter. You will never see them again. Enrich them as you please, with all my heart, but nothing more. In short, remain a Marquis, or be branded as a felon. Take your choice.
sp.stage: Enter Dubois, R. H.

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: Her ladyship has returned, my lord, and begs your lordship's presence in her apartment.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Her ladyship has doubtless to announce to you the consent of the Count de Cremancé to your marriage with his daughter. [In under tone.] Marquis and Millionaire! What can you want more ? Ah ! my lord, don't forget that you owe all this to chance—and me!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: You are a fiend incarnate! [Exit hastily door R. H.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside.] The devil himself in person, if you like— for your compact is signed, and in my keeping. I have a mortgage on this fine heiress's dowry; therefore, Michel, marry her you shall. [Perceiving Dubois.] What are you doing there, sir? Your place is in the ante room.

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: You told me to inform you when Madame de St. Prie arrived.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Is she there? Show her in at once. [Exit Dubois L. H.] I guess the object of her visit. She has heard of our return, and wishes to embrace her son. A pathetic scene of melo-dramatic recognition—"Mother !" "My Child!" No, I've quite difficulty enough, without that. It won't suit me at all. It's very touching on the stage, but I can't allow it.
sp.stage: Enter Madame de St. Prie, L. H.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Are you the Marquis's Valet de Chambre ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Will you inform him that Madame de St. Prie would speak with him.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [respectfully] No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Her own interest, no less than that of my master, forbids Madame de St. Prie from seeing her son.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Her son, you know then—

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I know everything. It was with me that the late Marquis left all his instructions. I am, so to speak the guardian of his son. Now, although it would gladden me to allow the mother to embrace her long lost child, she must restrain her impatience till that son is married. I know the young Marquis well. He would never consent to see his mother as a stranger— he would avow you at once, and publicly.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p:
Do you not see Madam, that such an avowal would inevitably break off his pending marriage with one of the highest families in France ? You are supposed to be dead, living, they would have to acknowledge you. The prejudices of the class are so strong, that rather than receive one of your humble birth, they would decline the alliance; remain in the
background till the marriage is over, and I shall be the first to bring your son to your arms.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: It is a cruel necessity, but I must submit, give him this portrait of his father, from—

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: A friend of his mother.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: So be it, a friend of his mother—I will write to him. [Goes to table and writes, L. H.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I will fetch you a taper ! [Exit door, R. H.
sp.stage: Victor enters, as if seeking some one, L. H.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Where is this Gaspard, whom I was to meet ? they told me he was here—a lady!

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Monsieur Victor!

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Madame de St. Prie! you remember me, Madam ?

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Oh ! yes. Your story interested me. I have also learnt your attachment to Mademoiselle de Cremancé, and its unhappy results—but I may serve you possibly more than you imagine, in that quarter.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: You, Madam!

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Hush!—not a word here. Come to me this evening. Silence!
sp.stage: Enter Gaspard with taper.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Madam, if I may be allowed—Who is this ?

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.

p.stage: [taking the taper and sealing the letter.]

sp.p: Thank you!

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Is your name Gaspard?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: At your service.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: My name is Victor, and I am here by appointment !
sp.stage: [gives note.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Victor! [aside.] The devil! [aloud.] I have business with you. sir. [aside.] Egad ! I was just back in time—a moment more, and all might have been discovered—I hope they have met by accident.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: You will give the Marquis this note, with the miniature.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Certainly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: Good day, Monsieur Victor. I shall expect you this evening.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Without fail, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside.] Eh ! they are acquainted, then !
sp.stage: [Exit Madame de St. Prie L. H. —Gaspard watching her, is not aware that in putting down the miniature, it has fallen on the ground. Victor perceives it there, and picks it up.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: You have dropped the miniature. [As he is about to give it, his eye rests on it.] How strange!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [hastily taking it from him.] What's strange ?

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p:
That portrait is the image of—a person—yes, it must be my generous protector; to whom I was indebted for
my education at the College of Beauvais.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside] I thought as much—and now it's beyond all doubt! [aloud] And yet I presume your protector could not very well have been the Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: This the Marquis de Melcy? oh no, then I am of course mistaken.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: But to business, you have applied for the place of Secretary? [aside] Which I must take good care you don't get— this is a young man who must travel.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Your note led me to hope—

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Employment certainly. The place of Secretary is already disposed of, but from all I hear of you, I feel so much interest in your welfare, that you may rely upon my doing my utmost—[aside]—to get you out of the way. [aloud] Are you fond of travelling?

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: My most ardent desire is to be able to quit France for ever.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Indeed, how lucky! I have it in my power to promote you to a most important post—the superintendance of one of the Marquis's estates in St. Domingo. But there is a difficulty, I fear an insurmountable one—you must leave Paris this very night, in order to reach Bordeaux in time for the next vessel; in three days you must embark.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Nay, I am ready to depart at once!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: But have you not an appointment for this evening with Madame de St. Prie ?

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Oh! that is of no consequence, Madame de St. Prie is a stranger to me—

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside] So much the better.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: She has a kind desire to serve me, but alas! her hope of doing so, I know to be a fallacy. I must not give up the substance for the shadow.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Indeed then your fortune lies before you! Be at the Fleur de Ly's, in the Palais Royal in an hour's time, I will send you there your letter of instructions, and the money for the voyage. Energy and speed are required, and you're the man we want. [aside] The very man, and I wish he were on the sea, with all my heart, at this moment.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: In an hour I will be there. [Aside.] Yes, absence
will be best. For her 'twill be oblivion—for me, death.
sp.stage: [Exit L. H. D.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Come, there's one plague out of the way, and without much trouble either.
sp.stage: Enter Dubois L. H.

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: Sir, a man who calls himself Alcide, wishes to—

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Alcide what ?

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: He merely said Alcide.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: But Alcide is no name !
sp.stage: Enter Alcide L. H.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [entering.] Excuse me, it is the name of an honest man; a little rare, enough to make the bearers of it a little aristocracy of themselves. I am the Syndic of the Millers.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Syndic!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [putting on his hat.] Nothing less, footman.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And what do you want with me, Syndic ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Nothing, footman! I never deal with valets and lacqueys. Where is your master ? I come to him as ambassador from the ladies.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Ladies ! What ladies ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: The ladies of the market, who are come to offer a bouquet of welcome to the Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Very well, I will receive them directly.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: You receive them! No, will you though ? Well, that is condescension! Why, young man, when we go to Court, the King leaves his council to receive us. If he were to send his Prime Minister, we should be affronted. No, we must have the young Marquis, not his lacquey. Go and fetch him—carry him here if necessary, but be quick about it, for the Majesty of the Market, is terribly impatient; and our ladies are apt not to measure their language when irritated.
sp.stage: Enter the Countess and Michel R. H.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Who are all these people I see in the Court-yard ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [taking off his hat.] The great lady !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: The ladies of the Market solicit the honor of presenting a bouquet to the Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A deputation from the Market! They must be received. It is a privilege recognised even by the Court itself.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: One sees that your ladyship is a woman of the world; a lady of the highest breeding.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: The Syndic of the Market, whom they have appointed their ambassador!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: They could not have made a better choice.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Your ladyship is too flattering. [Aside.] She is a woman of enormous breeding !

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Marquis, this visit will amuse you, and serve to shake off awhile the sudden melancholy which has seized upon you. While you receive the bouquet, I will see that a collation be prepared, worthy of these good people's merit.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [aside.] She is a woman in a thousand! I never met with such high breeding! [Aloud.] This is the way we are received at Court; no sooner do we appear, than the scullions fly about like mad.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Follow me, Gaspard.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Good day, Ambassador! [Exit with Countess, L. C.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [Looking after Gaspard] If ever that ape falls into my hands, I'll dust his laced jacket for him, I promise him!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [aside.] My courage has failed me. Gaspard, the infamous Gaspard, can destroy me with a breath. There is no help for it now. Though innocent at heart, appearances are against me, and not a voice but would condemn me !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Humph ! the Marquis is not as well bred as his aunt.
sp.stage: [He goes to the door L. H. which he flings open, Madeleine, Javotte, and the Market Women enter followed by Thérèse, who carries the bouquet.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Allow me to present to your Lordship the Mother of the Market. If not the oldest, she is the most respected among the middle aged, and the most eloquent among all. Oratory is her special gift. Oh, such a tongue ! such epithets! especially when aggravated. Don't blush Madeleine, the Marquis is all attention. Present—fire!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [aside] The Marquis! [approaches and looks at him who cannot see her] It's he !

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: I give you my word my Lord, that I have dished up nothing expressly for the occasion. Impromptu speeches with me always want a good deal of preparation. But Javotte here, my niece, makes her first attempt to day, and she shall address you with the speech I made his Majesty on his recent return to Paris. It has only been served once, and is as fresh as ever.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: It's as good as new!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Now Javotte, clear you voice, and don't be frightened! [aside] And don't forget to say Marquis, instead of Majesty.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: " Marquis ! you have long been away from us, you are now come back— and France possesses one good man the more."

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: That's all. And then the King kissed me !

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: And then the King kissed me. [Madeleine checks her.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Well Madam, such being the custom—if you will allow me—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [aside] It is his voice !

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: No Monseigneur, that honor is for the bearer of the bouquet.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: And without any ill compliment to Madeleine, Marquis you'll be no loser by the exchange.
sp.stage: Gaspard appears, L. C.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside] This folly not over yet!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: But where is she ? come forward child
sp.stage: [She takes Thérèse by the hand, and leads her face to face with Michel, who recognises her and is troubled.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Thérèse ! [aside to Gaspard] My wife !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [who has come down, near him] His wife!
sp.stage: [Thérèse after some hesitation presents the bouquet, without a word. Michel after a moment's hesitation, accepts it.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Now for the kiss. On both cheeks, in the good old style. [Michel kisses her, on the forehead.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [aside] There's a fellow for you! call that a kiss! his aunt would have done it better than that, I know.
sp.stage: [Michel troubled by the scrutinizing gaze of Thérèse, lets fall the bouquet, which Gaspard hastily picks up.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside to him] Take care!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: And now, how about some refreshment ? the heat makes one thirsty. Besides, I was thirsty at starting !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [hastily] The refreshments are waiting.
sp.stage: [He throws open the door, L. C. and discovers a table, sumptuously provided.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Now ladies to business!
sp.stage: [All enter the room, except Thérèse, who remains immovable, with her eyes fixed on Michel.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [at the back] Thérèse ain't you coming ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: No, I have a word to say to the Marquis.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside] She has recognized him !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: She's going to ask him for his custom.
sp.stage: [The doors close upon the Women and Alcide.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Will the Marquis order his valet to leave us ?
sp.stage: [Michel hesitates, and then makes a sign to Gaspard.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside to Michel] Remember, Marquis—silence or the galleys. [Exit Gaspard, L. C.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [sinking into a chair] The Galleys!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [approaches him slowly] Marquis, I am Thérèse, Thérèse Bonneau, of Clermont Ferrand, who there married, Michel the foundling. Did you never hear speak of me ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [after a struggle] Never!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Never?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: No—I—I—do not know you.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: It is not possible such a likeness can exist! Features, expression, voice, all! [Michel is about to go, she stops him] One moment, Marquis, but one. I came not here to offer you that bouquet. The thought of any rejoicing at such a moment would have been revolting to me—I should have been at home, weeping the bitter tears of helpless desolation, had not a gleam of hope drawn me to your presence. Instead of these holiday clothes, I should have crouched beneath my widow's weeds—[getting nearer]—for I am a widow Marquis, a broken-hearted widow ! [pauses for a moment, then aside] It is not Michel—thus unmoved—it cannot be.
sp.stage: [Bursts into tears

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [kindly] Pray, pray compose yourself.

sp.speaker: Therese.
sp.p: [aside] His voice! again his voice!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [aside] My resolution will not hold good against this ! [aloud] Tell me—tell me—what can I do to serve you ?

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: Michel, is it possible you can behold me thus, and yet your heart remain silent ? Does not the memory of the past, speak within you ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: I can only repeat—I—I never saw you till this moment.

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: [half stupified] Oh no! Michel could not have said that—my misery is complete, Michel is dead!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [aside] Her anguish is terrible, but the brand of infamy—never ! [Sinks into chair.

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: I humbly ask your pardon for what I have said, you must have thought me mad, and to be frank with you, I fear my poor brain is wandering, I have suffered so much ! But you have just left Saint Domingo, 'twas there my dear husband died. He left me to seek his fortune, he cajoled me into letting him depart. It broke my heart to give consent, but he wished it, and his wish to me was law.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: And have you never heard of him ?

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: Yes, twice; the first time—two years after he left us, oh! it made me so happy—but since then, I have waited again, three long years, counting the days, the hours, and each night as I have rested my aching head upon my lonely pillow, I have said—"To morrow —I must hear to- morrow." Even yesterday, I said the same. To day all hope is gone—for they have brought me the certificate of his death!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [aside.] The forgery of that heartless villain ! There lies my fate. And the certificate bears the name of Georges Michel ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Would that be a proof ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Beyond all doubt! [agitated by her scrutiny — aside.] I have not the force left to battle longer!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: It is no proof. No, none to me ! While I look at you, while I listen to your voice, I cannot persuade myself that Michel is dead—that I shall never see my husband more—that our dear Edouard will never throw his little arms around his father's neck!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [softening.] Edouard!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
