sp.p: [rapidly and in a lower tone] An angel boy ! whom I taught to pray each night for his father, who dying, knew not that he left an orphan child!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: My son ! Have I then a son ? [rising.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [aloud.] Ha! I knew that you were Michel !
sp.stage: [embraces him.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [looking round.] Silence !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: And you had the heart to say—you did not know me!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Thérèse, if you but knew what I suffered in saying that.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: I believe it—your heart is still unchanged, Michel —for, at the name of our child, you could not smother the cry of nature. But why this silence still? why do you deny me? And how did you become the Marquis de Melcy ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: You shall know all—but not now, not here.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: You had always a presentiment of a noble origin— but why did you not write, and inform me of your good fortune ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Prudence commanded my silence.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Prudence!—I do not understand. Had you but said, I am well—I am happy—I think of you—I love you as of old—I should have asked no more. But living to send me a certificate of your death ! Explain that —Michel, explain that !

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: I sent it not, Thérèse—I knew not of it—on my soul, I did not!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Who then prepared it?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Ask me no more. Let it suffice you for the present, to know that it is necessary for me to gain time to combat the haughty pride of my family, who would annul our marriage if they knew it.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Annul our marriage. They cannot!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: They can, Thérèse, they can. Be ruled by me. My ambition was, to make you rich and happy—that end is on the point of being realised—but to attain it, the world must remain in ignorance that your husband lives. [Thérèse starts.] For a few days only perhaps—a few days on which all depends, you will keep my secret, will you not Thérèse ? I entreat you for my sake, for your own sake, for the sake of our boy. You will keep it ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [giving him her hand] I will do all you ask,—I can refuse you nothing!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [tenderly.] Thérèse!
sp.stage: Enter Dubois, L. H.

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: My lord, the Notary from the Count de Cremancé is in the Countess's apartment. He desires me to say the contract of marriage with Mademoiselle de Cremancé awaits your signature. Exit, L. H.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [with force.] Ha! 'twas for this then that I was to remain silent! Villain!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Thérèse!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: The mask of hypocrisy and falsehood is torn from your face! In a few days you would marry with another! Not while I live! I retract my promise! —Michel! avow me as your wife, [going] or I publicly declare myself? Which shall it be ? Marquis ! I give you four-and-twenty hours to decide !

div.stage: [Music — Throws open the centre doors violently. The Women and Alcide are discovered at the table — they rise, glass in hand, on seeing Therese, who stands at the centre door, looking indignantly at the Marquis. Gaspard is at one of the side doors watching them.
Tableau.

div.head: Act VI.
div.stage: A Room at Therese's.
In the centre a large glass door with muslin curtains drawn over it, leading into a side street. Doors R. and L.H.
Marie discovered in a melancholy attitude, seated at a table L.H., with a lamp upon it.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I dare not go home, and yet I should do so. Poor Bonneau ! how grieved he was at having given way to his passion ; and how melancholy he seemed, when he started to go to the Marquis. What will be the result of this interview! I dread to think of it! Oh ! I am well punished for my error.
sp.stage: Enter Bonneau. At the sight of him, Marie seems fixed to the spot with shame. He stops a moment, looks at her with tenderness, and opens his arms.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Marie! dear Marie! [She rushes to him.] You see you are forgiven !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Not by myself, Bonneau.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Nay, Marie, I was as much to blame as you—perhaps more so. I was the cause of all.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Of course I was! I know your heart too well, Marie. If you had thought that the money did not belong to us, you never would have touched it.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Never! never! Oh! why Bonneau, why did you conceal it from me ? Could you not trust me ? The very mystery you made, aroused my curiosity, and the temptation was too great!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Well, the evil's done, and let it be forgotten. Besides, the Marquis has given me time.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: You have seen him ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: And told him everything. An honest man is always eager to face his creditor—its only the shuffler who avoids him.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Oh ! you were right to seek him.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: And I was rewarded. If you had only seen the way I was received. The generous young Marquis wanted to give me a receipt at once—but that wouldn't do for me. No ! no! the sacred deposit must be restored, and so I told him.
sp.stage: Thérèse enters at back, and places her cloak on the chair R. H., while Bonneau is speaking.
sp.p: But I was proud at the confidence he placed in us, and left the house with a heart relieved. The Marquis de Melcy is worthy of his name.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: The Marquis de Melcy is a villain !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Thérèse! What do you say ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: I say the Marquis de Melcy is Michel! My husband!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Your husband!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Oh! I recognised him this morning, but thought that I was mad! But when I confronted him face to face but now, in his own house—calmly and deliberately—all doubt disappeared. 'Twas in vain he refused to acknowledge me, I knew he was my husband!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Do you mean what you are saying ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: I swear it, in the face of Heaven! And yet, when I was alone with him—when with a breaking heart and tearful eyes, I said to him—" Michel, I am your wife—Thérèse!'' He, Michel—my husband—replied, " I do not know you!"
sp.stage: [Bursts into tears.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Then you see, my poor child, its clear you were—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Hold, father, and hear me out. Convinced that I was not mistaken, I spoke to him of Edouard—his child! At that name he softened, and confessed everything at once.

sp.speaker: Marie and Bonneau.
sp.p: Confessed !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Everything ! But entreated me—implored me for my own sake—for his—for the sake of our child—to keep our marriage secret for a few days ! Fool that I was! weak, credulous fool! Deceived by his hypocritical tears, and my own yearning heart, I consented. And why ? Do you know why Michel implored this silence? Do you know why our union was to be kept secret? To deceive me again! To marry another, whom he would have betrayed as he has me! Sits R.H.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Michel alive ! But you received the official certificate of his death!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Of course, she did—I read it myself. And now I see his object plainly. He did not choose to make his wife a Marchioness, and so would have made her a widow. What infamy ! Thérèse, that man never loved you! Forget him, and rejoice in the barrier he has raised between you. If he looks upon us in our humble, station with disdain, let us view him in his proud position with contempt.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [rising.] No, mother, not so. I envy not his title nor his love, but another woman shall never bear a name which, by right, belongs to me. I should myself become an accomplice in his crime, were I to promote it by my silence. My child shall not be an orphan while his father lives, and is Marquis de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Thérèse, you are right! It si a crime of which Michel would be guilty, and silence in the presence of crime, is not resignation, but infamy.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: I have given him twenty-four hours to reflect—it is too much ! This very night I will seek him again—you will both accompany me. We'll take Edouard with us, and see if Georges Michel, Marquis de Melcy, will dare to have his wife and child spurned from his door !

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Well said, Thérèse! I'll go and fetch your marriage certificate! We'll be armed with that, at any rate; and if all else fail, we have a last resource—a Court of Justice. If Michel will not recognise you, the law will. There are no rich and poor there—the law is for the whole world! [Exit, R. H.
sp.stage: At this moment Gaspard enters C. with the Countess.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [introducing the Countess.] This is the place—pray walk in, Madam. That is Thérèse Bonneau !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Who have we here ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [recognising Gaspard.] Gaspard! My husband's valet!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I am the Aunt of the Marquis de Melcy !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [aside.] Michel's Aunt doesn't promise much!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Her ladyship wishes to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Oh! my daughter is quite ready to listen to any explanation !

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Explanation!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Oh ! we have the honor of being addressed by her mother, then ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: You have. She will not deny her relationship, whatever other people may do.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [dusts a chair with his handkerchief, and presents it to the Countess.] Remember, Madam, that we have only four- and-twenty hours allowed us, to turn a Market Woman into the Marchioness de Melcy.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: [in an under tone.] Absurd!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: If we can obtain her voluntary renunciation of her husband, so much the better. If we fail, we must have resource to the more violent measure.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Now, Madam, I await your commands.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Yes, we are ready to hear you. [Sits.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I have but just learnt the tie that unites you to my noble nephew.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Its no fault of ours that you didn't know it sooner.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [with joy.] Ah ! and did Michel then himself, inform you ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: No! it was I who revealed all to her ladyship, unknown to the Marquis, and at the risk of his anger. He may discharge me, but I have discharged my duty, and my conscience is at rest.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: What an honest fellow !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [to Countess.] And you have come here at once to fetch me?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: [embarrassed,] To fetch you.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [smiling.] No—not exactly.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No—no—only to talk over the family affairs, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: [hurt] The family affairs!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: To talk business, in short.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [interrupting.] That's it—to talk business !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: There can be no business to discuss between us— You are the Marquis's only relation, I am his wife. I would it were in my power to do you more honor, by my birth and education; but under your guidance, madam, I hope that I shall improve the one, and have the other forgiven.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: If you will take the trouble to recollect, you will understand, that at the time my nephew married you, he did not suppose that there was any disparity between you.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Oh ! pardon me, he knew it perfectly.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside.] Come, that's pretty strong !

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: We peasants are as scrupulous of our honor, as you are of yours, madam ; and we look upon it as derogatory, to ally ourselves to those who cannot avow their family. Michel was in that position—a foundling—but I loved him—I had confidenee in his affection, and in his probity. In spite of all that could be said against him, I listened only to my heart; which said, no matter what his birth, an honest man cannot be unworthy of an honest woman !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Oh ! what then, the condescension was on the side of the Bonneaus?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Of course it was !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Undoubtdedly. Now perhaps you will say that it is the de Melcys' who have to blush for that alliance. If so, let, Michel remember the courage with which I braved the prejudices of my class—and imitate it, by renouncing the false pride of his.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Fairly put, Thérèse, and I am sure the Marquis—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: We will end this useless discussion if you please, at once. [draws forth a paper, which Gaspard presents to Thérèse]. I have only one word to say,—sign this, and name in return, what sum you please, I pledge my word it shall be yours!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [rising.] What!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Madam, but I do not understand you.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Its clear enough, too, I think. Her Ladyship generously places herself entirely at your discretion—she offers you a fortune!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: In exchange for your departure from Paris.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And your promise never to return. In fact, your consent to annul your marriage.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Are you aware, madam, that what you propose is neither more nor less than infamy ? The very thought of it is an outrage.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Allow me to tell you, Madam, that you must be either very bold, or very imprudent to come here, here in the very heart of the market—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: In my own house, to try and buy my honor!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: You don't know where you are! You don't know the volcano you are standing upon ! [Countess rises]

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Or to whom you speak, madam. You forget, that she, whom you have just outraged, is a woman whose education has been neglected; who knows not how to restrain her language ; whose indignation may cause her to forget the respect which she owes to herself and you.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: In a word, madam, to the Queen of this Market! Ay, and who has as much pride as the King upon his throne. The Market Women suffer insult from no one, and fear not to assert their rights against the highest in the land.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Ladies! ladies! [aside.] we've got into the Market with a vengeance!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Oh ! fear nothing. You Madam have forgotten who I am, but I shall not forget who you are. Tell Michel who doubtless sent you, that an honest woman does not sell her husband, nor deny her child!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Once more reflect—

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: I have reflected. When Michel was poor, and friendless, I said to him, "There is my hand; my house is your home." To-night before an hour has passed, the Marquis de Melcy shall receive me into his.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Enough Madam, we shall see. Come Gaspard!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside to her] There's not a moment to loose, we must at once to the Officer of Criminal Appeal.
sp.stage: [Exit with Countess, C.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: It's lucky they're gone. I could'nt have kept off much longer.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Oh, I did not fear my anger, but my grief. I would not have wept before her, for worlds.
sp.stage: [Sits down and weeps.
Enter Victor, C.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: May I speak to you Madam? oh! I will not detain you long, but your daughter has been so kind to me, that I could not leave, without saying farewell.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Are you going to leave us then! to quit Paris ?

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: France—and for ever.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Wherefore ?

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: It must be so, I cannot stay to see Mademoiselle Cremancé the wife of another.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [recollecting] Mademoiselle de Cremancé! yes that was the name they uttered, and is it her you love ?

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Mademoiselle de Cremancé! who is to marry the Marquis de Melcy ?

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Then dismiss your fears good friend, that marriage will not take place.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: What do you say ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: I say that never will Mademoiselle de Cremancé be Marchioness de Melcy while I live. I cannot yet tell you more, but I swear to you that that marriage will not take place.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: How strange ! this is the second assurance I have had to day. Oh, dared I but hope!
sp.stage: Alcide enters at the door, C.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: May I come in ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Of course, I don't know why you ask, for you never wait for an answer.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Monsieur Victor, remain at all events, for a few days.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: I will. I will see you and Madame de St. Prie once more, before I decide. [Going C.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: That's right, stay and pass the carnival with us, we're all preparing for jollity to-night. It's the affiancing of Brididi and Javotte, too. There'll be dancing and music in front of the fountain, and a grand supper at the Fleur de Ly'.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Thank you, Alcide; but such joyous doings are only for those who are happy. [Exit C.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: If that's the case, I'm sure I ought not to go there either.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: What Syndic, you not happy ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: No but I hope I may be so in time, if I can only follow the advice of Madeleine. She has given me up in despair as a husband for Javotte, so now she can advise disinterestedly.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: And what is it that she advises you to do, to be happy ?

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [with resolution] Why then, since you ask—[aside] My time's come—so here I go—she can't eat me after all—but I can't tell you before Marie.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Oh don't let me stand in your way, flower of modesty. I'll go and fetch Edouard, who is going out with us. [Exit R. H.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Look here, Thérèse! You are a widow—I am a bachelor; you're lovely—I'm not bad looking. You've some money—I've an old uncle crippled with the rheumatism, who'll leave me all he has in the world, except the rheumatism. Can't we put all this together ? If so, I remain where I am—if not, say the word, and I'm off to Marseilles.

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: Alcide, you must not go.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [uncertain.] Eh! not go!

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: I cannot be your wife; but you are my friend, my truest friend ! I have need of you, and you will remain.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [sighing.] I'll stay!

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: I have a service to ask of you!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Something to ask of me ? A service ? Thérèse, don't ask, command !

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: I am going out presently on very important business.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: I understand, and you wish me to go with you. I'm ready ! Let the Carnival go to the devil! Here I am.

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: No, that is not it, Alcide. Be here tomorrow by break of day, and if I have not returned, nor sent you word where I am, go you straight to the house of the Marquis de Melcy—insist upon seeing him. And if his Porter refuse you the door—

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: I'll get in at the window.

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: Then ask the Marquis boldly, what he has done with Thérèse, his wife !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: His Wife!

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: No questions! If the Marquis refuse to answer, I am in peril, and in that case, act as if you heard me, say "Alcide, my friend, save me !"

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: I don't understand a word, but never mind that! Had'nt I better go with you now ?

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: No; to-night my father will accompany me.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Oh! he'll do. He's a rock! I can trust you with him. Till daybreak to-morrow, then, good by, and good luck! [Aside, and heaving a heavy sigh.] Oh! [Exit C.

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: [alone.] His heart, will not fail me. I may rely upon him. But what can keep my father ? [Taking up her cloak.] Oh ! I cannot wait longer—I must go without him. Enter an Officer at the back. Three others remain at the door. They are dressed in black.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: You are Thérèse Michel?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: I am. What would you with me ?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: You must follow me!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Follow you ? Where ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [appearing at door.] To the Bastile!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [overwhelmed. [ Oh, Michel! Michel!
sp.stage: [Gaspard puts out the lamp and undraws the Curtains of the door, through which is seen a Hackney Coach. Men with torches stand by it. The steps are down, and Thérèse is hurried into it, and driven off L. H.
During this Bonneau and Marie enter with Edouard H.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: All dark ! Thérèse!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Where is she ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [at the door.] In prison.

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: In prison!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Gone!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: For ever.

sp.speaker: Edouard.
sp.p: [kneeling to Gaspard.] Oh Mamma! not gone to prison.
sp.stage: [Clings to Gaspard's knee, who break away. Edouard falls on his face. — Music.

div.stage: Tableau.

div.head: Act VII.
div.stage: The Fountain of the Innocents by Moonlight.

The Streets and Windows are illuminated. The Stalls of the Market lighted with little lanterns, and the whole effect of a Carnival Fete apparent. People of all sorts in fancy dresses, masked and otherwise, are grouped about the stage. An open carriage, full of Masqueraders, stands at the back.
Madeleine and the Market Women and Millers are discovered dancing. The dance ends as the curtain rises.

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Bravo, ladies ! Here's Brididi and Javotte. [calls to Alcide] Now, Syndic, we are only waiting for you.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [appearing at a window, B. H. in flat.] One moment, Madeleine; as soon as the flowers are in my hat. Go on, I'll join you directly. [Exeunt Madeleine and Others.
sp.stage: [The rest of the Market Women then arrive in procession followed by a string of children, two and two, dressed as little Millers and Market Girls, and terminated by the water barrel and donkey of Bonneau, decorated with leaves and flowers, led by a little Cupid. Javotte seated in front, and Brididi astride on the barrel, with a wreath of vine leaves on his head, and a goblet in his hand. A dance of Market Girls and Children then takes place and a Character Dance by Miss Rosina Wright, dressed as a Market Girl.

[At the end of these dances, the open carriage at the back is driven off, followed by the procession, in the same order as it arrived, and by all the Masqueraders, leaving the stage quite clear of people. As soon as they are off, Alcide enters, R. H.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p:
All gone, and without waiting for their Syndic! that's respectful, however ! But I'll astonish them, in spite of themselves. I'll jump into a hackney coach, and get there before them now. [looks out] Not one on the stand, I declare—how provoking! Here comes one though. There's some one in it,
but never mind that— have it, I will, if the King has hired it! I am the King of this Market, and they're in my dominions.
sp.stage: [A Hackney Coach drives across the stage from R. H., a man is on the box with the coachman, and two are behind.

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: Hoigh! out of the way there—you'll be run over.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Not I! on the contrary—I'm going to get in—I've taken you!

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: But I'm hired already !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: That's nothing!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [from within, putting down the window.] Alcide, my friend, save me! save me!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Thérèse's voice! where do want to go ?

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: To the Marquis de Melcy's !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: And where are you taking her ?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: To the Bastile !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Not if I know it. You must first get my permission !

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Seize that fellow, and take him to the guard house!

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Seizeme! I'll duck the whole party in the fountain first.
sp.stage: [He jumps up — knocks the coachman over the other side, and pulls the other man off the box. The two who are standing behind, crawl over the top of the coach and are successively pulled off. A conflict ensues, and while Alcide is engaged with two of the men, the third stands on the steps of the Fountain, and attacks him. Alcide knocks one down, and throws the other — then turns upon the man behind him.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: As for you, you whipper snapper, I'll soon cool your courage!
sp.stage: [He seizes him, and throws him into the basin which being of Real Water, ends the fight with a splash. Alcide then jumps upon the box.

div.stage: [Whips the horses and drives off, L. H.

div.head: Act VIII.
div.stage: The Fleur de Lys, brilliantly Illuminated-

Through large open arches at the back, is seen the Palais Royal by moonlight, as if considerably below. A long table at the back, at which are seated Cabri, Brididi, Madeleine, Javotte and all the Market Women at supper. At the opening of the scene, various Masks are grouped about, and the Symphony to Javotte's song is playing.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.l: Crowned with success will be my lot,
Happy Javotte! happy Javotte !

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Crowned with success will be her lot,
Happy Javotte! happy Javotte!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.l: All I would have on earth I've got,
Happy Javotte! happy Javotte !

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: All she would have on earth she's got,
Happy Javotte ! happy Javotte !

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.l: Regale then lads and lasses,
To-night here jolly and merry we'll be;
Come girls, fill up your glasses,
And drink to Brididi!
Brididi! Brididi! Brididi! Brididi! Brididi! Brididi!
Brididi! Brididi! Brididi!
Brididi!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.l: Soon will be tied the nuptial knot,
Happy Javotte! happy Javotte !

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Soon will be tied the nuptial knot,
Happy Javotte! happy Javotte !

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.l: Then gaily back to work we'll trot,
Happy Javotte! happy Javotte!

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Then gaily back to work we'll trot,
Happy Javotte ! happy Javotte!

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.l: Content with honest labour,
Dull care's all folly and fiddle-de-dee,
We'll dance to pipe and tabor,
Eh ! won't we, Brididi ?
Brididi! Brididi! Brididi! Brididi! Brididi! Brididi!
Brididi! Brididi! Brididi!
Brididi!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: [rising] Ladies of the Market! As I pay for the supper, I consider I buy the right to address you after it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hear! hear !

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: The happiness of Madeleine Richard is this day complete. Indeed I may say—as so many have said before me —that this is the proudest moment of my life.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hear! hear!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: This day my, niece, Javotte, has been triumphantly received into the bosom of our honorable Market! This day she has been affianced to a worthy lad—bow, Brididi! —and this day week she will be married to him. Having opposed the match for years—having thrown every obstacle I could think of, in the way of her happiness, I consider I have done my duty as an affectionate relation—let her now do her's. My prejudices against the lad are all removed, and the magnificent truth shines forth in all its beauty — that virtue must prevail at last.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hear! hear!

sp.speaker: Madeleine.
sp.p: Javotte, the speech is with you—I've done—and will now sit down amidst tumultuous cheers. [all applaud.

sp.speaker: Javotte.
sp.p: [rising.] Friends, I'm short—very short —and you know it—but short as I am, my speech is shorter. I have been admitted to the rights of the Market, through your kindness—I thank you for it. Take care you don't entrench upon those rights, or you'll repent it. In a week I shall be Brididi's wife— a good wife—a gentle one—Let him make a good husband, or— he'll know where the broomstick hangs. I say no more. [sits.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hear ! hear ! [All laugh and applaud.
sp.stage: Enter Victor in Domino and Mask, at Door L. H.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: Madame de St. Prie has not arrived yet—nor the Marquis either, who was to meet her here. I am first at the rendezvous. I know not wherefore, but a vague hope seems to whisper courage to me. I think I see her coming now.
sp.stage: (Goes towards a lady, masked, who has seated herself in the back ground, and beckons to him. He approaches her, and seats himself beside her, conversing earnestly )
Enter Michel, in Domino and Mask, at Door L. H.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: The resolution I have taken, is the only one that can restore me to that tranquility of conscience, which my error has banished. Thérèse shall have ample reparation. No longer will I stoop to the base cowardice which lends itself to crime—the threats of Gaspard shall no longer avail. Let him speak out—let them suppose me his accomplice—condemn me as such—I care not ? Let the whole world believe me guilty, so that Thérèse—Thérèse forgive me !
sp.stage: Enter Countess, Door L. H.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Marquis, finding your carriage was at the door, I ordered your coachman to drive me to you; as I have been seeking you everywhere, to accompany me to the Count de Cremancé.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Madam, I am sensible, deeply sensible of your kindness in promoting this alliance for me : but I must with pain inform you, that it cannot take place.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: With still more pain, it is my duty to inform you, Marquis, that it must and will.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: But I have myself broken it off!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You have done nothing of the kind.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: I have written to the Count de Cremancé !

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: But your letter did not reach him. Here it is.
sp.stage: [Returns him the letter.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [firmly.] Madam, this struggle between us must cease at once—learn then—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: That you are married to Thérèse Bonneau—a Market Woman, I believe they call her. I know that already, but it makes no difference—that marriage is void!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p:
Void! not so. To annul it, my consent must be
obtained, and that I will never give—do not hope it! I have too long sacrificed my feelings to considerations of rank and fortune. I will not sacrifice my honor and my love. I cannot consent to cast from me in prosperity, the woman who accepted me in poverty ! [Going L. H.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Where would you go ?

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: I go to seek my wife!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: And let loose the tongue of scandal for no purpose!
You will not find her!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: What do you mean ?
sp.stage: Enter Gaspard, Door L. H.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Madam, your orders are executed.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Orders! What orders ? And against whom?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: [heard without, L. H.] I tell you I know the Marquis is here !
sp.stage: Enter Bonneau and Marie, Door L. H.
sp.p: There, I said so !

sp.speaker: Madeleine and the Others. ]
sp.p: Ah ! Père Bonneau and Marie at last!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: One moment, friends!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: It is Michel!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Who is this ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: Who is this, madam ? Ask the Marquis.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Will he dare look me in the face, and say, "I don't know you ?"

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Bonneau, he will look you in the face, and say, " Father, I know you well; I honor you—I embrace you!"

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: There, madam, you see who this is, now.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Then give me back my daughter, whom you have had cruelly arrested, and sent to prison.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: To prison ? Thérèse in prison !

sp.speaker: Madeleine and the Rest.
sp.p: In prison ! What's that ? Thérèse in prison!

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Back, friends—do not interfere !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: [approaching Countess.] Yes, madam, your noble nephew has had her sent to prison, that she may not be able to tell his high born friends that the Marquis de Melcy is her husband.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: But I have the marriage certificate here! here with me ! and yet, to recover my daughter, I will not produce it. I will forget that she is your nephew's wife ! I will forget—deny it! I will declare that he is not Michel! Oh ! madam, implore his pity for me—implore him to give me back my child.
sp.stage: [Kneels to her.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p:
Blind, foolish man! Do you not see that I, whom
you accuse, suffer as much as you do, and that it is she, whose aid you beg, who is the cause of all our misery ?

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: I thought so ! I never liked her, from the first.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: She! Do you hear that, madam ? What, then, have you done with my daughter ?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You shall know all, as soon as this disgraceful marriage is annulled.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: Annul the marriage ! No one can do that!

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: No! not even such a great lady as you!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Wherever she may be, I will publicly claim her as my wife!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Go, then, claim her at the gates of the Bastile!
sp.stage: [Exit Door, L. H.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: The Bastile!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: The Lettre de Cachet that sent her there, must have been obtained in my name—my name shall now secure her release.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You're under a slight error, Marquis. The Court of Criminal Appeal forbids your approaching her. You will will never see her more.
sp.stage: Enter Alcide with Thérèse Door, L. H.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Room there, for the Marchioness de Melcy!

sp.speaker: Michel and Gaspard.
sp.p: Thérèse !

sp.speaker: Madeleine and the Others.
sp.p: Thérèse !
sp.stage: Marie goes to door L . H. and brings on Edouard.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Yes Thérèse ! who has come hither to demand, in public, her title of wife! who has come to make her rights, and those of her child, respected! Marchioness, or Market Woman, no one need blush for Thérèse Michel!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Well said Thérèse, well said !
sp.stage: [Alcide makes sign to them to be silent.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Thérèse, my own Thérèse ! and so I once more see you near me.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [surprised] How's this ! my father, my mother, by your side, and you speak to me thus tenderly!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: My heart is full, dearest Thérèse, they shall separate us no more. Persecution threatens me, but I will brave it. I will brave all for, your sweet sake.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: [aside to him] All, even the galleys!

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Again that man!
sp.stage: [The masked Lady seats herself at a table close behind them, and pays great attention.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p:
Are you at all aware whither your madness is hurrying you ? we may as well speak plainly, now that we are in the bosom of our family, for the moment is arrived when further delicacy would be misplaced. But I will not speak too loudly, lest the rest of your family there should hear us—and
when I have revealed to you your whole position, I think your wife herself will be the first to insist upon the marriage being annulled, for she will learn that her cherished husband is a felon.

sp.speaker: Bonneau, Marie and Thérèse.
sp.p: A felon!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: The name he bears, obtained by fraud, belongs to another, he is not the Marquis de Melcy!

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: I am not the Marquis de Melcy ?
sp.stage: [The Masked Lady beckons Victor, who comes forward, and stands behind her.

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: He has robbed another of the name !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: [confidently] Look in his face father, he is innocent!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: I wanted a Marquis de Melcy, and I made one ! I wanted a Marquis de Melcy, who would owe all to me ! I found you an orphan, poor, yet ambitious—poverty made you credulous, and easily moulded—the clay was at my hands, and from it I modelled the Marquis I wanted—you are he !

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: And the will of the late Marquis was not authentic ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Perfectly authentic, I simply substituted the name of Michel for that of Victor.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Victor!
sp.stage: [The Masked Lady leans her arm on Victor's shoulder, and prevents him from rushing forward.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: Villain ! and why did you deceive me! why did you not let me perish where I was ?

sp.speaker: Bonneau.
sp.p: And how do we know that this is not also false ?

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: Oh no father, this time he speaks the truth.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And now perhaps, you understand why I have at last made a clean breast of it before you all?

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: Yes! that we may be silent, that we may resign ourselves, that we may become your accomplices, is not that your object ?

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: That's it exactly. [Alcide steals out unobserved.

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: Miserable wretch! but you will be disappointed. When I prayed for the return of my husband, I did not pray to have him rich, but honest. Michel, raise your head, for you are not the accomplice of such a thing as this. Nay you shall restore his name and fortune to the real Marquis, for I know where to find him.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: I! all that this wretch has told me, for the sake of forcing me to commit a crime, I can use, to restore to a poor Orphan the name and fortune he has robbed him of.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Not quite so fast, if you please ! Michel, you belong to me, by right of salvage! I don't make Marquises every day, and I can't afford to give them up so readily. Pay the money as agreed between us, or we go to the galleys together.

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: But he is innocent!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: What Judges will believe him so ?

sp.speaker: Therèse.
sp.p: I will be his witness.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: You! his wife !

sp.speaker: Marie.
sp.p: We will all bear him witness.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: In vain! There is but one living witness who can avail.

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Victor!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Victor! And he has quited France for ever.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: [comes forward.] You are mistaken, he is here!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Victor!

sp.speaker: Mad. St. Prie.
sp.p: [taking off her mask] Yes, Victor ! Marquis de Melcy, and my son. [All rise from the table and listen.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Not gone!

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: The only living witness who can avail, and who will declare the innocence of the husband; of his benefactress. [Offering his hand to Thérèse I will be his defender, as you were mine in my adversity. There stands the only felon !
sp.stage: [Pointing to Gaspard.

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: And he had better stay here no longer.
sp.stage: [He is going, but is met by Alcide.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: No thoroughfare ! but to the Galleys !

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: The Galleys ! Never!
sp.stage: [He rushes to the Balcony, jumps on the parapet, and is on the point of precipitating himself from it.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Hold ! you cannot be allowed the luxury of suicide! You are now a prisoner. If you attempt to move, I treat you as an escaped convict, and shoot you like a dog!

sp.speaker: Gaspard.
sp.p: Be quick, then, for I have the start of you. The law is in my own hands, agd thus I—

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Fire!
sp.stage: [The Soldiers, who have been secreted behind the Counter by Alcide, unseen by Gaspard, discharge their muskets. He falls over the parapet.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: He who deceives all the world, should die deceived.

sp.speaker: Michel.
sp.p: [embracing Thérèse.] Thérèse !

sp.speaker: Thérèse.
sp.p: Michel?
sp.stage: [A group is formed by persons principally interested. The supper party, and the whole of the people in Carnival dresses, who have been attracted by the volley of musketry, are grouped behind.

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: [holds up a glass in the centre.] Long live the Marquis de Melcy!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Long live the Marquis de Melcy !

sp.speaker: Alcide.
sp.p: Health to Michel and Thérèse !

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Health to Michel and Thérèse! [Music.

div.stage: Tableau. - End
